[HISTORY: Adopted by the Board of Commissioners of the Township of Upper Dublin
7-14-1998 by Res. No. 1666. Amendments noted where applicable.]
GENERAL REFERENCES
 
Pensions—See  Nonuniformed employers pension plan—See Ch. A262.
Ch. 35.
 
ARTICLE I
Pension Plan and Pension Fund
§ A261-1.   Establishment of pension plan and pension fund.
The township hereby continues its municipal pension plan and municipal pension
fund for the benefit of police officers employed by the township who shall
receive honorable discharge by reason of age and service, or disability. The
pension plan shall be known as the “Upper Dublin Township Police Pension Plan.”
The pension fund shall be known as the “Upper Dublin Township Police Pension
Fund” (“pension fund”). The pension plan and pension fund are established
pursuant to Act 600. 1 1
1. Editor’s Note: See 53 P.S. § 767.
 
Notes
1    Editor’s Note: See 53 P.S. § 767.
§ A261-2.   Assets and liabilities.
All township or other assets set aside to provide for pension benefits under
this pension plan or any prior plan of benefits for police officers shall be
held in the pension fund. All pension benefits paid to members and terminated
members shall be paid from the pension fund. Required contributions as
described in §
A261-51, annual appropriations of the township, payments from the Commonwealth
Treasurer and all other funding sources shall be paid into the pension fund.
ARTICLE II
Membership
§ A261-3.   Definitions.
As used in this resolution, the following terms shall have the meanings
indicated:
   MEMBER—Each police officer who is employed by the township and subject to
the provisions of civil service, on the effective date of this pension plan.
“Member” also means each police officer who is hired by the township after the
effective date of this pension plan.
   TERMINATED MEMBERS—Any former police officer who has retired or terminated
his employment with the township before the effective date of this pension
plan.
§ A261-4.   Rights affected.
Terminated members shall not be entitled to any rights and benefits under this
pension plan. Rather, terminated members shall receive the benefits described
in the pension plan document in effect on the date of their termination of
employment or retirement, whichever was earlier.
ARTICLE III
Maintenance of Pension Fund
§ A261-5.   Source of funding.
The pension fund shall be maintained by:
   A.   Payments made by the Commonwealth Treasurer to the Township Treasurer
from moneys received pursuant to the Municipal Pension Plan Funding Standard
and Recovery Act, Act of December 18, 1984, P.L. 1005, No. 205, as amended, 53
P.S. § 895.101 et seq. (“Act 205”), and allocated for retirement or disability
benefits for members and terminated members. Payments from the Commonwealth
Treasurer shall be delivered by the Township Treasurer to the pension fund
within the statutory time period following receipt by the Township Treasurer.
   B.   Required contributions by each member as set forth in § A261-51 herein
and in the current collective bargaining agreement. Required contributions
shall be made through payroll deductions on salary, excluding overtime pay as
described in §
A261-36, received by members in the same frequency that members receive their
salary. Required contributions shall be paid into the pension fund at the end
of the month of their deduction.
   C.   Annual appropriations to the pension fund made by the township.
   D.   Gifts, grants, devises or bequests made to the pension fund.
§ A261-6. Payments exclusive to fund.
All payments described in §
A261-5 shall be deemed to be a part of the pension fund and shall not be
applied to any other pension fund or account or disbursed in any manner, except
as provided herein.
§ A261-7. Payments to be a charge on fund only.
Payments for pension benefits under the pension plan shall be a charge only
upon the pension fund and not upon other moneys or funds of the township.
§ A261-8. Payments from Commonwealth Treasurer.
The annual payment made by the Commonwealth Treasurer to the Township Treasurer
pursuant to Act 205 for retirement or disability benefits under the pension
plan shall be used to reduce the pension plan's annual "normal cost" defined in
Section 102 of Act 205 2 as that portion of the actuarial present value of the
pension plan benefits and expenses which is allocated to the plan year by the
actuarial cost method.
2. Editor's Note: See 53 P.S. § 895.102.
§ A261-9. Normal cost.
The pension plan's normal cost shall be comprised of the following:
   A.   The unfunded liability of the pension plan. "Unfunded liability" means
the present value of the unfunded pension benefits accrued under the pension
plan during all years prior to the current year. The unfunded liability of the
pension plan shall be amortized over 25 years.
   B.   The future service liability of the pension plan. "Future service
liability" means the present value of pension benefits accrued during the
current year.
   C.   Allowable administrative costs for the management and administration of
the pension plan and the pension fund.
§ A261-10. Allowable administrative costs.
"Administrative costs" means those costs described in Section 402(9) of Act 205
3 and Auditor General Municipal Pension Bulletin No. 1-88. Allowable
administrative costs shall satisfy the following criteria:
   A.   The cost shall be directly associated with the pension plan.
   B.   The Pension Committee shall monitor any services provided to ensure
that the cost is necessary, reasonable and beneficial the pension plan and
pension fund.
   C.   Appropriate records of costs are kept as necessary for the Auditor
General audit.
3. Editor's Note: See 53 P.S. § 895.402.
§ A261-11. Other administrative costs.
Any administrative costs that do not satisfy the criteria described in §
A261-10 shall be provided for by appropriation made by the Board of
Commissioners of the township.
§ A261-12. Payments from any other source.
Any other moneys paid into the pension fund shall be applied equally against
the member and township portions of the normal cost, unless otherwise
specified.
ARTICLE IV
Pension Committee of Trustees
§ A261-13. Establishment of Pension Committee of Trustees.
The township hereby establishes the Township of Upper Dublin Police Pension
Fund Committee of Trustees ("Pension Committee") to whom the township delegates
authority to administer the pension plan and pension fund.
§ A261-14. Membership of the Pension Committee.
The Pension Committee shall consist of five Trustees as follows:
   A.   The President of the Board of Commissioners or an individual appointed
by the Board of Commissioners.
   B.   The Township Manager.
   C.   The Township Finance Director.
   D.   Two police officers elected by a majority vote of the members of the
pension plan.
§ A261-15. Chairman.
The Chairman of the Pension Committee shall be the President of the Board of
Commissioners or the Commissioners' representative.
§ A261-16. Compensation.
Pension Committee Trustees shall serve without compensation.
§ A261-17. Term.
Each Trustee shall be appointed for a two-year term. Trustees may be
reappointed or reelected.
§ A261-18. Plan Administrator.
The Pension Committee shall appoint a Plan Administrator to handle the day-to-
day operation of the pension plan and pension fund.
§ A261-19. Minutes and records.
The Plan Administrator shall keep minutes of the Pension Committee's
proceedings and all dates, records and documents pertaining to the Pension
Committee's administration of the pension plan.
§ A261-20. Indemnification.
No Trustee shall be liable for any act or omission of any other Trustee, nor
for any act or omission on his own part excepting only his own willful
misconduct. The township shall indemnify and save harmless claims or
liabilities arising from acting as a Pension Committee Trustee, excepting only
expenses and liabilities arising out of the Trustee's own willful misconduct.
Trustees shall serve without bond.
§ A261-21. Limitations on voting.
No Trustee shall vote on any matter directly related to the payment of benefits
to the Trustee.
§ A261-22. Voting and voting results.
The action of the Pension Committee shall be determined by the vote or other
affirmative expression of a majority of its Trustees. All actions of the
Pension Committee shall be certified by its Chairman and attested to by the
Plan Administrator.
§ A261-23. Meetings.
The Pension Committee shall meet at least semiannually and at other times at
the call of the Chairman or the request of the majority of the Pension
Committee.
§ A261-24. Powers and duties.
The Pension Committee shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To administer the pension plan and pension fund in accordance with the
Custodial Trust Agreement between the township and First Union National Bank,
N.A or such other appropriate agreement of trust approved by the Board of
Commissioners. The Custodial Trust Agreement permits money manager(s) approved
by the Board of Commissioners to manage and operate the pension fund and to
receive, hold, invest and disperse any sum or sums as may be necessary to cany
out the pension plan and all other applicable statutes, ordinances and
regulations.
   B.   To provide guidance to any money manager(s) of the pension fund for the
investment of all moneys deposited in such pension fund and the reinvestment of
all earnings of the pension fund.
   C.   To adopt rules and regulations for the governance of the affairs of the
Pension Committee to better enable it to carry out its powers and duties
imposed hereunder.
   D.   To employ, retain and compensate, upon approval of the Board of
Commissioners, actuaries, accountants, auditors, attorneys, money managers and
investment consultants as it may deem necessary to carry out its duties
hereunder.
   E.   To make all decisions pertinent to the pension plan regarding pension
payments to any applicant or participant, or for the return of any required
contributions to any person who may be entitled to the same under the pension
plan.
   F.   To designate a pension fund custodian for the depository of all pension
fund assets.
   G.   To deposit into the pension fund all contributions required under
applicable law and in accordance with the advice, counsel and direction of the
pension plan's actuary.
   H.   To make all decisions in accordance with the terms of the pension plan,
including but not limited to the following:
      (1)   To determine all questions relating to the eligibility of police
officers to become members in the pension plan.
      (2)   To compute and certify to the pension plan custodian the amount and
kind of benefits payable to members.
      (3)   To make and publish such rules and regulations for the
administration of the pension plan as are not inconsistent with the terms of
the Agreement of Trust or applicable law.
§ A261-25. Use of evidence.
The determinations by the Pension Committee shall be made based upon the
submission of such evidence as the Pension Committee shall require.
§ A261-26. Determinations to be final.
The determination of the Pension Committee in each case shall be final and
conclusive and entitled to deference by any third party unless such
determination is arbitrary and capricious.
§ A261-27. Limitations on powers.
Notwithstanding anything herein, the Pension Committee shall not have the power
to amend the terms of the pension plan or take any action that would directly
or indirectly increase the township's funding obligation under the pension plan
other than in the normal course of determining benefits under the pension plan.
ARTICLE V
Role of Actuary
§ A261-28. Approved actuary.
An approved actuary is a person who has at least five years of actuarial
experience with public pension plans and who is either enrolled as a member of
the American Academy of Actuaries or enrolled as an actuary pursuant to the
Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.
§ A261-29. Employment of approved actuary.
The Board of Commissioners shall, from time to time, employ an approved actuary
at a compensation to be determined by the Board of Commissioners. In selecting
an approved actuary, the Board of Commissioners shall consult with the Pension
Committee.
§ A261-30. Duties of actuary.
The actuary employed by the Board of Commissioners shall provide the following
services on behalf of the pension plan:
   A.   Prepare all required actuarial studies, in accordance with all
applicable laws, including but not limited to Act 205 and Act 600.
   B.   Determine the pension plan's annual normal cost as described in §
A261-9 and the amount which the township shall contribute to the pension fund
each year after taking into consideration the other sources of revenue for the
pension fund.
   C.   Such other reasonable and necessary actuarial services as the Board of
Commissioners or the Pension Committee shall direct.
ARTICLE VI
Retirement Benefits
§ A261-31. Eligibility for normal retirement benefit.
A member shall be eligible to receive a normal retirement benefit when he has
satisfied the following requirements:
   A.   The member has completed a minimum aggregate total of 25 years of
service; and
   B.   The member has attained age 50.
§ A261-32. Normal retirement age.
The first day of the month following satisfaction of the requirements described
in §
A261-31 shall be the member's normal retirement age.
§ A261-33. Year of service.
   A.   "One full year of service" means 365 completed days of employment. A
"partial year of service" means any portion of a year of employment that does
not constitute a full year based upon the ratio that the number of such days
bears to 365.
   B.   Subject to Subsection C below, a member's years of service shall be
calculated from his date of employment or reemployment with the township as a
police officer to his date of separation from employment or retirement from the
township, whichever is earlier.
   C.   The following periods of time shall not interrupt a member's employment
status for purposes of calculating the member's years of service, provided that
such periods are less than one year, though such periods need not be
continuous:
      (1)   Vacation days.
      (2)   Accrued time days.
      (3)   Leaves of absence.
      (4)   Periods of suspension from duty.
   D.   Family Medical Leave Act. Effective August 5, 1993, a member shall be
credited with completed days of employment for purposes of satisfying the years
of service vesting requirement described in §
A261-44 for any period during which he is absent from work on unpaid leave
under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. However, no member shall be
credited any days of completed service for leave on account of the Family and
Medical Leave Act for purposes of satisfying the years of service eligibility
requirement described in §
A261-31.
§ A261-34.   Final average salary.
“Final Average Salary” means the average monthly salary of the member during
the last 36 months of employment.
§ A261-35.   Salary.
   A.   “Salary” means the sum of the following calculated on an annual
calendar-year basis:
      (1)   All taxable payments from the township, excluding overtime.
      (2)   Any pre-tax contributions to a deferred compensation plan under
Section 457 or 414(h) of the Internal Revenue Code.
      (3)   Any payments made pursuant to the Act of June 28, 1935, P.L. 477,
as amended, 53 P.S. § 637 and 638, commonly known as the “Heart and Lung Act.”
   B.   In no event shall a member’s salary used to compute his final average
salary exceed the following annual compensation limits:
      (1)   Two hundred thousand dollars for 1989.
      (2)   For 1990, 1991, 1992 and 1993, the limit set by the Internal
Revenue Service in accordance with Section 401(a)(17) of the Internal Revenue
Code.
      (3)   One hundred fifty thousand dollars for 1994 and 1995.
      (4)   One hundred sixty thousand dollars for the 1997 Plan Year.
      (5)   For all plan years after 1997, the limit set by Section 401(a)(17)
of the Internal Revenue Code, as adjusted for cost-of-living increases.
§ A261-36.   Actuarial equivalent.
“Actuarial equivalent” means a form of payment of the normal retirement benefit
that is of comparable value to any other form of payment.
§ A261-37.   Normal retirement benefit.
[Amended 1-9-2001 by Ord. No. 1054; 5-8-2001 by Ord. No. 1063; 7-10-2007 by
Ord. No. 1184; 12-11-2012 by Ord. No. 12-1263, § 1]
“Normal retirement benefit” means an amount that is equal to 50% of the
member’s final average salary.
   A.   Members. The normal retirement benefit for all members shall be a
monthly pension payable for the life of the member. Such monthly pension shall
be in an amount equal to 50% of the member’s final average salary commencing at
the member’s normal retirement age.
   B.   Survivor benefit. In addition, the surviving spouse of a retired member
shall be entitled to monthly payments equal to 60% of the member’s normal
retirement benefit. If there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse
subsequently dies, then the child or children of the member shall be entitled
to receive a survivor’s benefit equal to 60% of the pension which the member
was receiving or would have been receiving had the member retired at the time
of death. Such survivor’s benefit to the child or children shall continue until
the child or children reach the age of 18, or until age 23, if the child is
“attending college.” For purposes of this section, the phrase “attending
college” shall mean being enrolled in an institution of higher learning and
carrying a minimum course load of seven credits per semester. [Amended 7-10-
2007 by Ord. No. 1184; 12-11-2012 by Ord. No. 12-1263]
§ A261-38.   Length of service increment.
[Amended 7-10-2007 by Ord. No. 1184]
A member who completes 25 years of service shall receive an additional length
of service increment benefit which shall be added to the member’s normal
retirement benefit.
   A.   For officers retiring prior to July 1, 2007, the length of service
increment shall be $100 per month.
   B.   An officer retiring on or after July 1, 2007, who completes 26 years of
service, shall receive a $100 service increment. An officer retiring on or
after July 1, 2007, who completes years of service over 26 years shall receive
an additional $100/full year of completed service up to a maximum monthly
service increment of $500 for 30 or more years of completed service.
§ A261-38.1.   Early retirement benefit.
[Added 1-9-2001 by Ord. No. 1054]
   A.   There is hereby established an early retirement benefit which shall be
available to a member of the police force with 20 or more years of continuous
service who terminates employment prior to the completion of superannuation
retirement age and service requirements and who files a written application for
an early retirement benefit with the Upper Dublin Township Board of
Commissioners (“Board”).
   B.   The early retirement benefit shall become effective as of the date the
application is filed with the Board or the date designated on the application,
whichever is later, and shall be the actuarial equivalent of a partial
superannuation retirement benefit calculated as follows:
      (1)   A partial superannuation retirement benefit shall be determined by
applying the percentage that the member’s years of service bear to the years of
service that the member would have rendered had the member continued to be
employed until his superannuation retirement date to the gross pension amount
calculated using the monthly average salary during the appropriate period prior
to his termination of employment.
      (2)   The actuarial equivalent of the partial superannuation retirement
benefit shall be determined by actuarially reducing the partial superannuation
retirement benefit to reflect that it will commence on the effective date of
the early retirement rather than on the date on which the member would have
completed superannuation age and service requirements. The actuarial reduction
shall be calculated using the actuarial assumptions reported in the last
actuarial valuation report filed with the Public Employee Retirement Commission
under the act of December 18, 1984 (P.L. 1005, No. 205), known as the
“Municipal Pension Plan Funding Standard and Recovery Act” or “Act 205,” 53
P.S. § 895.101 et seq.
§ A261-39.   Preretirement survivor’s benefit.
The survivor of a member who, on the day of his death, was employed by the
township as a police officer and satisfied the eligibility requirements for a
normal retirement benefit as described in §
A261-31 shall be eligible for a preretirement survivor’s benefit.
   A.   Survivor. “Survivor” means:
      (1)   The surviving spouse of a member; or
      (2)   If no surviving spouse, the surviving minor children of a member.
   B.   Amount. The preretirement survivor’s benefit shall be equal to the
benefit such survivor would have received if the member:
      (1)   Had terminated his employment prior to his death;
      (2)   Had elected to receive a fifty-percent joint and survivor benefit
as described in §
A261-37B(2); and
      (3)   Had died the following day.
   C.   Duration. The preretirement survivor’s benefit shall be a monthly
benefit commencing on the first day of the month following the month in which
the member died, and terminating as follows:
      (1)   As of the date the surviving spouse remarries or dies; or
      (2)   If applicable, when the last of the surviving minor children
obtains age 18 or dies, whichever event shall occur first.
§ A261-40.   Disability retirement benefit.
A member shall be eligible for a disability retirement benefit on his
disability retirement date. No minimum years of service are required for
eligibility.
   A.   Disability retirement date. A member’s disability retirement date shall
be the day that the member is totally disabled as a result of a service-
connected disability. No disability retirement benefits shall be payable to a
member who has suffered a non-service-connected disability.
   B.   Amount. A member’s disability retirement benefit shall be equal to 50%
of the member’s final average salary. However, the disability retirement
benefit shall not be reduced by the amount of any payments for which the member
shall be eligible under the Act of June 2, 1915 (P.L. 736, No. 338), known as
the “Pennsylvania Workers’ Compensation Act,” 4  or the Act of June 21, 1939
(P.L. 566, No. 284) known as the “Pennsylvania Occupational Disease Act.” 5
   C.   Form of benefit. The disability retirement benefit shall be a monthly
pension for life commencing on the first day of the month following the month
in which the member became totally disabled.
   D.   Pension Committee. The Pension Committee shall have discretion to
determine.
      (1)   Whether a member has a total disability, based on consultations
with a medical examiner, who shall have the right to make such physical
examinations and other investigations as may be reasonably required to
determine total disability; and
      (2)   Whether a member’s total disability is a service-connected
disability or a non-service- connected disability.
   E.   Total disability. A member has a total disability if he is permanently
unable to perform the normal duties of a police officer by reason of physical
or mental impairment.
   F.   Service-connected disability. A service-connected disability is a
permanent injury that occurs in the course of, or results from, a member’s
performance of his duties as a police officer.
   G.   Non-service-connected disability. A non-service-connected disability is
a disability that does not occur in the course of, or result from, a member’s
performance of his duties as a police officer. A member with a non-service-
connected total disability shall be entitled to the following, at his option:
      (1)   A single lump sum payment of the amount in his total required
contributions as defined in §
A261-50 on the date he terminates employment with the township; or
      (2)   Vesting of his normal retirement benefit in accordance with §
A261-44, provided that the member satisfies the years of service requirement
for such vesting on the date of his termination of employment.
4. Editor’s Note: See 77 P.S. § 1 et seq.
5. Editor’s Note; See 77 P.S. § 1201 et seq.
§ A261-41.   Cost-of-living allowance.
   A.   Subject to the limitations described in Subsection B, a member
currently receiving a normal retirement benefit or an accrued normal retirement
benefit shall receive an annual cost-of- living allowance. The Pension
Committee shall determine the amount of the cost-of-living adjustment based on
the percentage increase or decrease in the consumer price index for the
immediately preceding calendar year and applied as the Acts of the Commonwealth
proscribe.
   B.   Amount. A member’s disability retirement benefit shall be equal to 50%
of the member’s salary at the time the disability was incurred, reduced by the
amount of Social Security disability benefits received for the same injury.
      (1)   No cost-of-living allowance shall exceed the percentage increase in
the consumer price index from the year in which the member terminated his
employment with the township as a police officer.
      (2)   The maximum annual cost-of-living adjustment for any year shall be
3%.
      (3)   No cost-of-living allowance may increase a member’s normal
retirement benefit or accrued normal retirement benefit to an amount that would
exceed 30% of the final average salary used to compute the member’s benefit.
[Amended 1-9-2001 by Ord. No. 1054]
      (4)   No cost-of-living allowance shall be granted if such cost-of-living
allowance would impair the actuarial soundness of the pension fund.
§ A261-42.   Temporary service.
Retired police officers shall be subject to temporary service from time to
time, as a police reserve in cases of riot, tumult or preservation of the
public peace, until unfitted for such service, when they may be finally
discharged by reason of age or disability.
§ A261-42.1.   Killed in service benefit.
[Added 7-13-2004 by Ord. No. 1133; Amended 5-11-2010 by Ord. No. 10-1231]
   A.   Effective April 17, 2002, if a member is killed in the line of duty for
the Township, and he or she dies survived by a spouse or dependent child or
children, then a monthly pension benefit of 100% of the member’s monthly salary
at the time of his or her death shall be paid to the surviving spouse until the
surviving spouse dies. If there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving
spouse subsequently dies, then the child or children of the Member shall be
entitled to receive a monthly survivor’s benefit equal to 100% of the member’s
monthly salary at the time of his or her death. Such survivor’s benefit to the
child or children shall continue until the child or children reach the age of
18, or until age 23, if the child is “attending college.” At the time at which
any surviving spouse has died and any dependent children have reached age 18,
or age 23, if the child is attending college, the benefit created under this
section shall terminate. No other pension benefit shall be paid by the Township
to the surviving spouse or dependent child(ren) of an officer who is killed in
the line of duty.
   B.   For purposes of this section, the phrase “attending college” shall mean
being enrolled in an institution of higher learning and carrying a minimum
course load of seven credits per semester.
   C.   Effective January 1, 2010, the surviving family of an officer who is
killed in the line of duty shall receive the benefits provided for and subject
to the terms of Act 51 of 2009, which benefits are paid exclusively by the
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. With the exception of any pension benefit to
which the officer was entitled prior to the officer’s death, solely by virtue
of the officer’s age and service as a Township police officer, and any other
non- pension, contractual benefits to which the officer and/or the officer’s
family may have been entitled prior to the officer’s death, the Township shall
not be obligated to pay any benefit to the family of an officer as the result
of the officer’s death, including, but not limited to, the killed in service
pension benefit which previously existed under Act 600 prior to the passage of
Act 51 of 2009.
ARTICLE VII
Vesting
§ A261-43.   Treatment of terminated vested member.
A member who terminates his employment with the township as a full-time police
officer for any reason other than for a service-connected total disability
before reaching his normal retirement age shall be entitled to his accrued
normal retirement benefit payable beginning on his superannuation retirement
date, provided that the member satisfies the requirements described in §
A261-44.
§ A261-44.   Vesting requirements.
A terminated member may vest his accrued normal retirement benefit if he
satisfies the following requirements:
   A.   The member has completed 12 years of service prior to his termination
of employment.
   B.   The member files a written notice with the Pension Committee within 90
days of the date the member terminates his employment with the township
expressing his intention to vest.
§ A261-45.   Superannuation retirement date.
The “superannulation retirement date” is the date a member would have satisfied
the age and service requirements described in §
A261-31 for a normal retirement benefit had the member not terminated his
employment with the township as a police officer.
§ A261-46.   Accrued normal retirement benefit.
A member’s accrued normal retirement benefit shall be determined by multiplying
50% of the member’s final average salary by a fraction whose numerator is the
years of service actually earned by the member and whose denominator is the
years of service required for the member to reach his superannuation date.
   SAMPLE CALCULATION
 
Actual years of service earned:                        14
Years of service required to meet superannuation date: 30
Final average salary:                                  $1,500
Fifty percent of final average salary:                 $750
14      X      $750                        $350
30
Accrued normal retirement benefit      =         $350
 
§ A261-47.   Commencement of accrued normal retirement benefit.
A member’s accrued normal retirement benefit shall be payable as a monthly
pension for the life of the member beginning on the member’s superannuation
date.
§ A261-48.   Refund.
If a member fails to satisfy the requirements for an accrued normal retirement
benefit described in §
A261-44, such member shall receive a single lump sum refund of his required
contributions in accordance with §
A261-55.
§ A261-49.   Military service.
   A.   Subject to Subsection B, a member who has been employed by the township
as a police officer for at least six months, and who thereafter enters into the
military service of the United States, shall be credited with years of service
equal to the period of time that the member spent in such military service,
provided the member returns to his or her employment with the township as a
police officer within six months after his separation from military service.
   B.   A member shall only be credited with years of service for intervening
military service if he is not entitled to receive retirement benefits for such
military service under a retirement system administered and wholly or partially
paid for by any other governmental agency.
   C.   Subsection B shall not apply where a member is eligible to receive or
is receiving military retirement benefits earned by a combination of active
duty and nonactive duty with a reserve or national guard component of the armed
forces.
ARTICLE VIII
Members' Required Contributions
§ A261-50. Required contributions.
" Required contributions" means the total amount of contributions each member
is required to contribute to the pension fund under this pension plan.
§ A261-51. Amount.
The amount of required contributions that each member shall pay, monthly, into
the pension fund shall not exceed the maximum annual amount set by Act 600 or
the member's salary, or the annual compensation limit under Internal Revenue
Code Section 401(a)(17) as further described in §
A261-35 herein. The amount of required contributions shall be set by resolution
by the Board of Commissioners in accordance with an existing collective
bargaining agreement which shall have been initially established based upon
actuarial recommendations. The amount of required contributions is set forth in
Schedule A attached hereto which may be amended from time to time as a result
of collective bargaining negotiations. 6
6. Editor's Note: Contact township offices for said Schedule A.
§ A261-52. Payroll deductions.
The Township Secretary is hereby authorized to establish a system of payroll
deductions necessary for the administration of the pension fund.
§ A261-53. Reduction or elimination of required contributions.
Required contributions may be reduced or eliminated provided that all four of
the following conditions are met:
   A.   A current actuarial study indicates that the condition of the pension
plan is such that the pension fund remains actuarially sound without the
reduced or eliminated required contributions.
   B.   An appropriation by the township will not be required to keep the
pension fund actuarially sound.
   C.   The Board of Commissioners authorizes by ordinance or resolution, on an
annual basis, any reduction or elimination of required contribution.
   D.   The reduction or elimination of required contributions will not cause
an actuarial reduction in normal retirement benefits.
§ A261-54. Pick up contributions.
Effective January 1, 1997, the township shall pick up each member's required
contributions. No member shall have the option to forego his required
contributions and receive an equal amount as compensation. A corresponding
reduction in the member's salary shall be made in the amount of the picked-up
required contributions. For purposes of the Internal Revenue Code, such picked-
up required contributions shall be treated as employer contributions pursuant
to Section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
§ A261-55. Refund of required contributions.
   A.   Any member who, for any reason whatsoever, shall be ineligible to
receive pension benefits under this pension plan shall be entitled to a refund
of any required contributions he made to the pension fund when the member
discontinues his employment with the township as a police officer.
   B.   Amount of refund. All refunds pursuant to Subsection A shall be equal
to the total amount of a member's required contributions contributed pursuant
to §
A261-51, plus the prorated amount of the net interest earned by the member's
required contributions while in the pension fund.
   C.   Form of payment. All refunds of required contributions shall be in the
form of a single lump sum payment.
   D.   Death of member. If a member's discontinuance of employment with the
township is due to the member's death, any refund of required contributions
shall be paid to the deceased member's designated beneficiary or, in the
absence thereof, to his estate.
   E.   Termination of pension plan or complete discontinuance of required
contributing. In the event that the pension plan may be terminated under
applicable state law and is terminated, or in the event of a complete
discontinuance of all required members' contributions to the pension fund, the
right of each member to his required contributions shall be nonforfeitable. The
nonforfeitable amount of each member's required contributions shall be the
amount described in Subsection B. Members shall be entitled to receive their
nonforfeitable required contributions in accordance with the terms of the
pension plan.
ARTICLE IX
Rollovers
§ A261-56. Transfer of distribution.
   A.   Effective January 1, 1994, a member or a member's surviving spouse who
is to receive an eligible rollover distribution, as defined in §
A261-57, may elect to have the amount of such distribution transferred directly
in a direct rollover to an eligible retirement plan, as defined in §
A261-57.
   B.   If a member or surviving spouse is to receive an eligible rollover
distribution of more than $500, he may choose to have part of the distribution
transferred directly in a direct rollover to an eligible retirement plan and to
have the remainder paid to him. The amount which is to be transferred must be
at least $500.
§ A261-57. Definitions.
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated:
   ELIGIBLE RETIREMENT PLAN —
   A.   In the case of a member, one of the following:
   B.   An individual retirement account or an individual retirement annuity.
   C.   A qualified trust if it is part of a defined contribution plan.
   D.   An annuity plan described in Section 403(a) of the Internal Revenue
Code.
   E.   In the case of a member's surviving spouse, an individual retirement
account or an individual retirement annuity.
   ELIGIBLE ROLLOVER DISTRIBUTION — A distribution from the pension plan that
is a single-sum payment (i.e, refund of required contributions). The dollar
amount of an eligible rollover distribution shall not include the portion of
such distribution that is a required minimum distribution under Section 401(a)
(9) of the Internal Revenue Code.
§ A261-58. Explanation to be provided.
Within a reasonable period of time before an eligible rollover distribution is
to be made, the Pension Committee shall provide the member or surviving spouse
an explanation of his right to elect a direct rollover and the federal tax
withholding consequences to him if he does not elect a direct rollover.
§ A261-59. Member or surviving spouse to provide information.
A member or surviving spouse who elects a direct rollover must provide all
information that the Pension Committee may require to complete the direct
rollover.
§ A261-60. Failure to elect direct rollover option.
A member or surviving spouse who is entitled to elect a direct rollover with
respect to all or any portion of a refund of required contributions from the
pension plan but who does not make any election shall be deemed to have
rejected the direct rollover option.
ARTICLE X
Maximum Benefit
§ A261-61. Applicability.
The provisions of this article shall be effective January 1, 1987, and shall be
construed to comply with Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code. The limits
on benefits described herein shall not apply to any benefit received on account
of disability.
§ A261-62. Limitation on combined annual benefit.
Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, in no event shall the
combined annual benefit attributable to the township's contributions payable on
a single life basis (or, if applicable, as a qualified joint and survivor
annuity) under this and any other defined benefit plan to which the township
contributes exceed the lesser of:
   A.   Ninety thousand dollars (as adjusted by the Internal Revenue Service to
reflect cost-of-living increases); or
   B.   One hundred percent of the member's average limitation compensation
during the three consecutive calendar years of participation hereunder in which
his limitation compensation is the highest.
§ A261-63. Limitation on retirement benefit.
If the retirement income benefit under the pension plan begins at or after age
62 but prior to the member's social security retirement age (SSRA), the
retirement benefit may not exceed an annual benefit of $90,000 reduced by:
   A.   In the case of a member whose SSRA is 65, 5/9 of 1% for each month by
which benefits commence before the month in which the member attains age 65; or
   B.   In the case of a member whose SSRA is greater than 65, 5/9 of 1% for
each of the first 36 months and 5/12 of 1% for each of the additional months
(up to 24) by which benefits commence before the month in which the member
attains SSRA.
§ A261-64. Limitation on benefits for members under 62 years of age.
If the benefit begins before age 62, the benefit must be limited to the
actuarial equivalent of the member's limitation for benefits commencing at age
62, with the reduced dollar limitation for such benefits further reduced for
each month by which benefits commence before the month in which the member
attains age 62. In order to determine actuarial equivalence for this purpose,
the interest rate assumption used by the pension plan may not be less than 5%.
§ A261-65. Determination of social security retirement age.
   SSRA is age 65 if the member was born before January 1, 1938; age 66 if born
before January 1, 1955; and age 67 if born after December 31, 1954.
§ A261-66. Minimum.
The reduction under §§
A261-63 and
A261-64 shall not reduce the dollar limitation of §
A261-62 below:
   A.   Seventy-five thousand dollars if the benefits begin at or after age 55;
or
   B.   If the benefits begin before age 55, the equivalent of the $75,000
limitation for age 55.
§ A261-67. Adjustment for members whose benefits begin after age 65.
If a member's retirement benefits begin after the member has attained age 65,
the dollar limitation in §
A261-62A shall be increased to its actuarial equivalent at the date of
commencement, using an interest rate of 5%.
§ A261-68. Members with 15 years of service.
For a member with 15 years of service, §§
A261-63 through
A261-66 shall not reduce the dollar limitation of §
A261-62A to an amount less than $50,000.
§ A261-69. Other plans.
Notwithstanding the limitations set forth in the other provisions of §§
A261-62 through §
A261-75, the benefits payable under this pension plan with respect to a member
shall be deemed not to exceed the limitations of §§
A261-62 through
A261-75 if:
   A.   The benefits payable with respect to such member under this pension
plan and all other defined benefit plans maintained by the township do not
exceed $10,000 for the plan year or for any prior plan year; and
   B.   The township has not maintained a defined contribution plan in which
the member participated.
§ A261-70. Members with fewer than 10 years of service.
   A.   If the benefit is payable to a member who has fewer than 10 years of
service in the pension plan at the time that retirement benefits begin, the
dollar limitation described in §
A261-62A shall be multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which is the
member's years of service in the pension plan (or part thereof) and the
denominator of which is 10.
   B.   If the benefit is payable to a member who has fewer than 10 years of
service at the time that retirement benefits begin, the percentage of earnings
limitation described in §§
A261-63 through
A261-66 and the special limits set forth in §§
A261-68 and
A261-69A shall be multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which is the
member's years of service and the denominator of which is 10.
§ A261-71. Determination of years of service.
   A.   For purposes of determining a member's years of service for the
adjustment to the dollar limitation of §
A261-62A required by §
A261-69A, the member shall be credited with a year of service (computed to
fractional parts of a year) for each computation period for which the following
conditions are met:
      (1)   The member is credited with at least the number of hours of service
required under the terms of the pension plan in order to accrue a benefit for
the computation period; and
      (2)   The member is included as a member under the eligibility provisions
of the pension plan for at least one day of the computation period.
   B.   If these two conditions are met, the portion of a year of service
credited to the member shall equal the percentage of a full year of service
credited to the member for such computation period.
§ A261-72. Years of service for disabled members.
A member who is permanently and totally disabled within the meaning of Section
415(c)(3)(C)(i) of the Internal Revenue Code for a computation period shall
receive a year of service with respect to that period.
§ A261-73. Fractional years.
For a member to receive a year of service (or part thereof) for a computation
period, the pension plan must be established no later than the last day of such
period. In no event shall more than one year of service be credited for any
twelve-month period.
§ A261-74. Reduction of limitations.
In no event shall the provisions of §§
A261-70 through
A261-75 reduce any of the limitations described in §§
A261-62 and
A261-68 an amount less than 1/10 of such limitation.
§ A261-75. Change in benefit structure; effect on members with fewer than 10
years of service.
Section
A261-70A shall be applied separately with respect to each change in the benefit
structure of the pension plan
§ A261-76. Other employee contributions.
Any contributions made by a member other than those described in Article VIII
shall be deemed to constitute a separate defined contribution plan. The benefit
subject to the limit of §§
A261-62 through
A261-75 shall not include any benefit attributable to such employee
contributions. The portion of the benefit attributable to employer
contributions and subject to §§
A261-62 through
A261-75 shall be determined by converting the employee contributions to an
annual benefit amount pursuant to Section 411(c)(2)(B) of the Internal Revenue
Code and subtracting such amount from the total annual benefit.
§ A261-77. Annual additions.
   A.   The annual additions under any defined contribution plan shall not
exceed the lesser of:
      (1)   Thirty thousand dollars or, if greater, one-quarter of the dollar
limitation in effect under Section 415(b)(1)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code;
or
      (2)   Twenty-five percent of such member's limitation compensation for
the year.
   B.   "Annual additions" shall mean the sum of:
      (1)   Employer contributions.
      (2)   Forfeitures.
      (3)   The member's own after-tax contributions.
§ A261-78. Participation in other contribution plans during limitation years.
If in any limitation year a member is also a participant in one or more defined
contribution plans sponsored by the township, the annual benefit referred to in
§§
A261-79 and
A261-80 shall be reduced, if necessary, so that the sum of the fractions
described in §§
A261-79 and
A261-80 do not exceed 1.0 for such limitation year.
§ A261-79. Defined benefit fraction.
   A.   "Benefit fraction" is a fraction, the numerator of which is the
member's projected annual benefit under the defined benefit plans sponsored by
the township in which he has participated, determined as of the close of the
limitation years of such plans, and the denominator of which is the lesser of:
      (1)   One and twenty-five hundredths x $90,000 (as adjusted by the
Internal Revenue Service to reflect cost-of-living increases); or
      (2)   One hundred forty percent of the member's highest average
limitation compensation over any three consecutive calendar years.
   B.   In calculating the adjustments required by §
A261-69 for purposes of determining the denominator of the defined benefit
fraction for any limitation year, the years of service that are used shall
include future years occurring before the member's normal retirement age. For
purposes of the preceding sentence, years of service may include the future
year which includes the date on which the member will reach normal retirement
age, provided that it can be reasonably anticipated that the member will
receive a year of service for such year. In projecting years of service for
future years, it may be assumed that a member is a full-time employee if he is
currently a full-time employee.
§ A261-80. Defined contribution fraction.
" Contribution fraction" is a fraction, the numerator of which is the sum of
the annual additions to the member's accounts under all defined contribution
plans sponsored by the township for all limitation years, and the denominator
of which is the sum of the lesser of the following amounts, determined for each
limitation year of service with the township:
   A.   One and twenty-five hundredths x $30,000; or
   B.   Thirty-five percent of the member's limitation compensation for such
limitation year.
§ A261-81. Definitions.
The definitions in this section apply for purposes of §§
A261-78 through
A261-80:
   PROJECTED ANNUAL BENEF'I'T' — The annual benefit to which a member would be
entitled under the terms of a defined benefit plan if he had continued
employment until his normal retirement date under such plan and if his
compensation for the purpose of such plan had continued at the same rate.
   ANNUAL ADDITION — Annual additions to a member's accounts under any defined
contribution plan for any limitation year means the sum of employer
contributions, forfeitures and the member's own after-tax contributions. A
defined benefit plan sponsored by the township to which nondeductible employee
contributions are made is considered to be a separate defined contribution
plan, to the extent that the employee contributions constitute annual additions
in the current and prior limitation years.
   PLAN YEAR — The calendar year.
   LIMITATION YEAR — The calendar year.
   LIMITATION COMPENSATION —
   A.   The member's wages, salary, fees for professional services and other
amounts received for personal services rendered in the course of employment
with the township, to the extent that such amounts are includable in gross
income, and regardless of whether an amount is paid in cash, including (but not
limited to) commissions paid to salesmen, compensation for services on the
basis of a percentage of profits, commissions on insurance premiums, tips,
bonuses, fringe benefits, reimbursements and expense allowances; foreign earned
income, whether or not excludable from gross income under Section 911 of the
Internal Revenue Code; taxable amounts received by the member through accident
or health insurance for personal injury or sickness or from a self-insured
medical expense reimbursement plan; moving expenses paid or reimbursed by the
township in excess of any amount deductible by the member; and wages or
payments in lieu of wages received on account of absence from work for
permanent and total disability.
   B.   Limitation compensation shall exclude the following:
      (1)   Contributions made by an employer to a qualified plan to the extent
that, before the application of Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code to
that plan, the contributions are not includable in the gross income of the
member for the year in which contributed.
      (2)   Employer contributions on behalf of an employee to a simplified
employee pension plan.
      (3)   Any distributions from a plan of deferred compensation, except that
any amounts received by an employee pursuant to an unfunded nonqualified plan
may be included in the year that such amounts are included in gross income.
      (4)   Other amounts which receive special tax benefits, such as premiums
for group term life insurance to the extent not includable in gross income, or
contributions made by an employer toward the purchase of an annuity contract
described in Section 403(b) of the Internal Revenue Code.
   C.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this pension plan, the annual
additions for any limitation year beginning before January 1, 1987, shall not
be recomputed to treat all of a member's own after-tax contributions as annual
additions.
§ A261-82. Adjustments for governmental pronouncements.
The dollar limitations described in §§
A261-62 through
A261-81 shall be adjusted in accordance with governmental pronouncements
stating the method and amount of such adjustments.
§ A261-83. Reduction of benefits accrued prior to limitation year.
   A.   The dollar limitations described in §§
A261-62 through
A261-81 shall not reduce any benefit which was accrued by a member under the
pension plan prior to the first day of its limitation year beginning in 1983,
using the applicable maximum dollar limitations then in effect; provided,
however, that this sentence shall not apply to any member unless he was a
member in the pension plan before January 1, 1983. For the purpose of this §
A261-83A, no change in the pension plan after July 1, 1982, and no cost-of-
living adjustment after July 1, 1982, shall be taken into account.
   B.   The dollar limitations described in §§
A261-61 through
A261-81 shall not reduce any benefit which was accrued by a member under the
pension plan prior to the first day of its limitation year beginning in 1987,
using the applicable maximum dollar limitations then in effect; provided,
however, that this sentence shall not apply to any member unless he was a
member in the pension plan on January 1, 1983. For the purpose of this §
A261-83B, no change in the prior plan after May 5, 1986, and no cost-of-living
adjustment after May 5, 1986, shall be taken into account. Any change in the
terms and conditions of this pension plan made pursuant to a collective
bargaining agreement ratified before May 6, 1986, shall be treated as a change
made before May 6, 1986.
§ A261-84. Plan years ending after December 31, 1982.
The township may elect to apply §
A261-83A with respect to any plan year ending after December 31, 1982, by
calculating the denominator under §
A261-80 using an alternate amount for all plan years ending before January 1,
1983. The alternate amount shall be equal to the amount determined for the
denominator under §
A261-80 as in effect for the plan year ending in 1982 multiplied by the
transition fraction. The transition fraction shall be a fraction determined as
follows:
   A.   The numerator shall consist of the lesser of:
      (1)   Fifty-one thousand eight hundred seventy-five dollars; or
      (2)   Thirty-five percent of the member's limitation compensation for the
plan year ending in 1981.
   B.   The denominator shall consist of the lesser of:
      (1)   Forty-one thousand five hundred dollars; or
      (2)   Twenty-five percent of 'the member's limitation compensation for
the plan year ending in 1981.
§ A261-85. Limitation years ending after December 31, 1986.
The township may elect to apply §
A261-80 with respect to any limitation year ending after December 31, 1986, by
adjusting the numerator under §
A261-80 by using an alternate amount for all limitation years beginning on or
before December 31, 1986. The adjustment is to subtract permanently from the
numerator of the defined contribution fraction an amount equal to the product
of Subsections A and B below:
   A.   The sum of the defined contribution fraction and the defined benefit
fraction as of the determination date, minus 1.0; times
   B.   The denominator of the defined contribution fraction as of the
determination date.
ARTICLE XI
Required Distributions
§ A261-86.   Latest commencement of benefits.
Distribution of a member’s benefits under this pension plan shall commence by
the April 1 that follows the end of the calendar year in which the member
attains age 70½ or retires, whichever is later.
§ A261-87.   Mandatory benefit commencement date.
“Mandatory benefit commencement date” means the April 1 described in §
A261-86 for each member.
ARTICLE XII
Miscellaneous
§ A261-88.   Payments to be free from all claims.
All payments under the pension plan shall not be subject to levy, attachment,
execution, garnishment or other legal process and shall be payable only to the
member or his designated beneficiary and shall not be subject to assignment or
transfer.
§ A261-89.   Modification.
The pension plan and pension fund established herein may be discontinued,
modified, altered, terminated or repealed according to law, by ordinance,
provided that Act 111 requirements have been met.
§ A261-90.   Gender.
As used in this pension plan, the masculine shall include the feminine and the
feminine shall include the masculine.
§ A261-91.   Revocation of prior enactments.
Any and all ordinances and resolutions heretofore enacted by the Board of
Commissioners providing for pensions and/or retirement benefits for police
officers employed by the township are hereby repealed, and any ordinance or
resolution or any part thereof conflicting with the provisions of this pension
plan shall be, and the same are, hereby repealed insofar as the same affects
this pension plan. Any police officer who shall have terminated employment
before the effective date of this pension plan and any dependent or beneficiary
shall be entitled to the benefits, if any, they were previously receiving.
§ A261-92.   Severability.
The provisions of this pension plan are severable, and if any section,
sentence, clause, part or provision thereof shall be held illegal, invalid or
unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision of the
court shall not affect or impair the remaining sections, sentences, clauses,
parts or provisions of this pension plan. It is hereby declared to be the
intent of the Board that this pension plan would have been adopted as if such
illegal, invalid or unconstitutional section, sentence, clause, part or
provision had not been included herein.
ARTICLE XIII
Deferred Retirement Option Program
[Adopted 12-11-2012 by Ord. No. 12-1263]
§ A261-93.   Definitions.
   DROP—Deferred Retirement Option Program.
   DROP ACCOUNT—Separate account created to accept DROP participants’ monthly
pension check while a DROP participant.
   POLICE OFFICER OR OFFICER—Police officer of Upper Dublin Township.
§ A261-94.   Eligibility.
Effective January 1, 2013, any officer who has reached his/her normal
retirement date based on age and service may elect to become a DROP participant
on the first day of the month following the attainment of the requirements
which is a minimum 25 years of credited service and attaining at least the age
of 50.
§ A261-95.   Written DROP election and letter of resignation.
An officer of the Upper Dublin Police Department electing to participate in the
DROP must complete and file with the Township Manager a “DROP option form”
prepared by Upper Dublin Township which shall evidence the officer’s
participation in the DROP. The form must be signed by the officer and submitted
to the Township Manager at least 30 days prior to the date on which the member
wishes the DROP option to be effective. The DROP option notice shall include a
binding, irrevocable and notarized letter of resignation to the Township
Manager, by the officer, that the officer shall resign from employment with the
Upper Dublin Police Department effective on a specific date (the “resignation
date”). In no event shall the resignation date be no more than 48 months from
the commencement of the officer’s DROP participation period. A DROP participant
may change the DROP termination date to an earlier date and no penalty shall be
imposed for early termination of DROP participation. An officer shall cease to
work as a Township police officer on the officer’s resignation date, unless the
Township terminates or honorably discharges the officer prior to the
resignation date.
In addition, all retirement documents required by Upper Dublin Township must be
signed and presented to the Township Manager for approval of retirement and
payment of pension. Once a retirement application has been approved, it is
irrevocable. The documentation that must be completed before an officer may
participate in the DROP shall contain an acknowledgment that any fees,
commissions and administrative costs attributable to the DROP participation
shall be paid out of the police pension fund in accordance with the pension
plan. The officer must agree to hold the Township harmless for any consequences
of the officer’s decision to participate in DROP including, but not limited to,
any tax consequences or implications of DROP participation and/or any monetary
loss incurred as the result of DROP participation.
§ A261-96.   Limitations during DROP period.
After the effective date of the DROP option and during the DROP period, the
officer shall:
   A.   No longer earn or accrue additional years of continuous service for
pension purposes.
   B.   No longer be required to make any pension contributions to the Upper
Dublin Police Pension Fund.
   C.   No longer be eligible for tuition reimbursement pay.
   D.   No longer be eligible for longevity increases.
   E.   No longer be eligible to access funds from the Upper Dublin Police
Codicil until after his/her resignation date.
§ A261-97.   Benefit Calculation.
For all retirement fund purposes, the length of service of a police officer
participating in DROP shall remain as it existed on the effective date of
commencement of participation in the DROP. Service thereafter shall not be
recognized or used for the calculation or determination of any benefits payable
by the Upper Dublin Township Police Pension Fund. The monthly average salary of
the police officer for pension calculation purposes shall remain, as it existed
on the effective date of commencement of participation in the DROP. Earnings,
increases in earnings and length of service increments after the DROP election
date or increases in earnings thereafter shall not be recognized or used for
the calculation or determination of any benefits payable by the pension fund.
§ A261-98.   Payments to the DROP account.
The monthly retirement benefits that would have been payable to the police
officer had the member elected to cease employment and receive a normal
retirement benefit, shall, upon the member commencing participation in DROP, be
paid into an account established to receive the participant’s monthly pension
payments. This account shall be designated the DROP account.
§ A261-99.   DROP account.
The Township shall establish a DROP account as an interest-bearing ledger
account in its police pension trust fund. The DROP account balance shall be
accounted for separately but shall not be physically segregated from other
pension trust fund assets. Interest shall be credited into the DROP account
monthly and shall be equal to the police pension fund’s actual interest earned
each month, but not less the 0% or more than 4.5% annually.
§ A261-100.   Accrual of non-pension benefits.
After a police officer elects to participate in the DROP, all other contractual
benefits shall continue to accrue with the exception of those provisions
relating to the police pension plan and those provisions listed in §
A261-96 above.
§ A261-101.   Payout.
Upon the resignation date set forth in the police officer’s DROP option notice
or such date as the Township separates the officer from employment, the
retirement benefits payable to the officer or officer’s designated beneficiary,
if applicable, shall be paid to the officer or beneficiary and shall no longer
be paid to the officer’s DROP account. Within 30 days following termination of
an officer’s employment pursuant to their participating in the DROP, the total
accumulated benefits in the officer’s DROP account shall be calculated and paid
out of the Upper Dublin Police Pension Fund to the officer in a single lump sum
payment or at the member’s option, in any fashion permitted by law. By
participating in the DROP, each officer must agree to hold the Township
harmless for any tax or other consequences flowing from the officer’s
disposition of the payout under this article.
§ A261-102.   Disability during DROP.
If a police officer becomes temporarily disabled during his/her participation
in DROP, that officer shall continue to participate in the DROP as if fully
employed. The officer shall receive disability pay in the same amount as
disabled officers that are not participating in DROP. In no event shall an
officer on temporary disability have the ability to draw from his DROP account.
However, notwithstanding any other provision in this section, if an officer is
disabled and has not returned to work as of his/her required resignation date,
then such resignation shall take precedence over all other provisions herein
and said officer shall be required to resign.
If an officer becomes permanently disabled during the DROP period, the officer
shall be honorably discharged from employment after the injury that prevents
the DROP participant from performing full police duties is deemed to be
permanent. On the date that the officer is deemed to be permanently disabled,
the officer shall, within 30 calendar days, obtain the contents of his/her DROP
account and, thereafter, commence receiving his/her normal pension benefit. An
officer who is participating in DROP must waive any claim to a disability
pension benefit should the officer become permanently disabled during the DROP
period.
§ A261-103.   Death during DROP.
If a DROP participant dies before the DROP account balances are paid, the
participant’s designated beneficiary shall have the same rights as the police
officer to withdraw or direct the DROP account balance. If a DROP participant
is killed in the line of duty, the participant’s survivors shall receive the
killed-in-service benefit pursuant to Act 51 of 2009. All amounts in the
participant’s DROP account at the time of his/her death shall be paid to the
participant’s survivors.
§ A261-104.   Forfeiture of benefits.
Notwithstanding an officer’s participation in the DROP, an officer who is
convicted or pleads guilty to engaging in criminal misconduct which constitutes
a “crime related to public office or public employment,” as that phrase is
defined in Pennsylvania’s Pension Forfeiture Act, 43 P.S. §§ 1311–1314, shall
forfeit his right to receive a pension, including any amounts currently
deposited in the DROP account. In such a case, the member shall only be
entitled to receive the contributions, if any, made by the member to the fund,
without interest.
§ A261-105.   Effect of qualified domestic relations order.
Rights under this plan shall be subject to attachment in favor of an alternate
payee as set forth in a qualified domestic relations order.
§ A261-106.   Construal of provisions.
An officer’s election to participate in the DROP shall in no way be construed
as a limitation on the Township’s right to suspend or terminate an officer for
just cause or to grant the officer an honorable discharge based upon a physical
or mental inability to perform his or her duties.
ARTICLE XIV
Non-Intervening Military Buy Back
§ A261-107.   Non-intervening military service time buy back. [Added 12-10-2024
by Ord. No. 24-1399]
The pension plan provides full-service credit for each year of active-duty
military service or fraction thereof based on the member’s Form DD214, not to
exceed five years, to a member who was not employed by the Township prior to
such military service, payable by the member.
The member shall pay the amount for the purchase of credit for military service
other than intervening military service that shall be computed by applying the
average normal cost rate for the pension plan as based upon the most recent
actuarial valuation, but not to exceed ten per centum, to the member’s average
annual rate of compensation over the first three years of service with the
Township and multiplying the result by the number of years and fractional part
of a year of creditable non-intervening military service being purchased,
together with interest at the rate of four and three-quarters per centum
compounded annually from the date of initial entry into service to the date of
payment. The members must pay for the purchase of non-intervening military
service time as a lump-sum deposit to the pension plan.
A member of the pension plan shall be eligible to receive service credit for
intervening or non-intervening military service provided that he is not
entitled to receive, eligible to receive then or in the future, or is receiving
retirement benefits for such service under a retirement system administered and
wholly or partially paid for by any other governmental agency with the
exception of a member eligible to receive or is receiving military retirement
pay earned by a combination of active duty and non-active duty with a reserve
or national guard component of the armed forces which retirement pay is payable
only upon the attainment of a specified age and period of service under 10
U.S.C. Ch 67 (relating to retired pay for non-regular service).
