2-9-1999 by Res. No. 1690. Amendments noted where applicable.]
GENERAL REFERENCES
 
Nonuniformed Employers Pension Plan — See
Ch. 35, Art. II.
ARTICLE I
Introduction
§ A262-1. Establishment of Pension Plan and Pension Fund.
The Township previously established and continues to maintain the Pension Plan
to provide pension benefits for its Members. In addition, the Township
previously established and continues to maintain the Pension Fund to hold
moneys set aside to provide pension benefits under the Pension Plan. All
pension benefits paid to Members and their Survivors shall be paid from such
Pension Fund. Unless otherwise specifically provided below, the terms of the
Pension Plan, as of the Effective Date and as may be amended from time to time
in the future, shall not apply to members who terminated employment with the
Township prior to the Effective Date; their benefits are determined in
accordance with the terms of the Pension Plan in effect at the time of their
termination of employment.
§ A262-2. Contributions to the Pension Fund.
[Amended 1-9-2001 by Ord. No. 1055]
Required contributions, as described in Article VIII, as well as annual
appropriations of the Township, payments from the Commonwealth Treasurer and
all other funding sources, as described in Article X, shall be paid into the
Pension Fund.
ARTICLE II
Definitions 1
1 Editor's Note: See also §
A262-35, Gender and number.
§ A262-3. Definitions.
The following words, when capitalized, shall have the following meanings unless
the context clearly indicates otherwise:
   ACCRUED PENSION — The monthly amount payable in the form of a Fixed Period
Single Life Annuity for 10 years, calculated by multiplying 1.35% of a Member's
Average Monthly Salary by a Member's total Years of Service as a Nonuniformed
Employee, provided that the number of Years of Service used in this calculation
may not exceed 30. [Amended 1-9-2001 by Ord. No. 1055]
   ACT 205 — The Municipal Pension Plan Funding Standard and Recovery Act,
Title 53 of the Pennsylvania Statutes 53 P.S. § 895.101 et seq., as amended,
which governs the operation and administration of the Pension Plan.
   ACTUARIAL EQUIVALENT — The equivalent value of different benefits under the
Pension Plan determined by using a 7% interest rate and the UP-1984 Mortality
Table.
   APPROVED ACTUARY — A person who has at least five years of actuarial
experience with public pension plans and who is either enrolled as a member of
the American Academy of Actuaries or enrolled as an actuary pursuant to Section
3042 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ("ERISA").
   AVERAGE MONTHLY SALARY — The average of a Member's monthly Salary during the
60 consecutive calendar months of active employment immediately preceding the
Member's termination of employment whether or not as a Nonuniformed Employee.
If a Member has been employed for less than 60 consecutive calendar months of
active employment upon his termination of employment, the average of his
monthly Salary during such months of active employment shall be used instead of
60 months. Calendar months during the sixty-consecutive-month period (or
shorter period, if applicable) for which a Member earns no Salary shall be
disregarded for the purpose of making this determination.
   BENEFIT COMMENCEMENT DATE — The first day for which a benefit is payable to
a Member under the terms of the Pension Plan.
   BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS — The Township of Upper Dublin Board of
Commissioners.
   CODE — The Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, or any successor
statute.
   DEATH BENEFIT — The death benefits provided to Survivors in accordance with
the terms of §
A262-13.
   DIRECT ROLLOVER — The direct transfer of certain lump-sum payments made
under the Pension Plan to:
   A.   Another retirement plan which is qualified under Code Section 401 (a);
or
   B.   An individual retirement account as described in Code Section 408.
   EARLY RETIREMENT AGE — The first age at which a Member is both at least age
55 and has completed at least 10 Years of Service as a Nonuniformed Employee.
   EARLY RETIREMENT DALE — The first day of the month coinciding with or next
following the Member's Early Retirement Age which is prior to Normal Retirement
Age.
   EARLY RETIREMENT PENSION — The early retirement benefits provided to a
Member in accordance with the terms of §
A262-6.
   EFFECTIVE DATE — For this amended and restated Pension Plan, February 1,
1999. The original effective date of the Pension Plan is May 1, 1968.
   FIXED PERIOD SINGLE LIFE ANNUITY — A Single Life Annuity with continued
monthly payments to a Member's Survivor for the remainder of the fixed period
in the event the Member dies, for a period of either five, 10 or 15 calendar
years as elected by the Member.
   HOURS OF SERVICE:
   A.   The Hours of Service credited to a Nonuniformed Employee under one or
more of the following categories:
      (1)   PERFORMANCE OF DUTIES — Each hour for which a Nonuniformed Employee
is paid by the Township for the performance of services for the Township.
      (2)   PAID ABSENCES — Each hour (not to exceed eight hours per calendar
day) for which a Nonuniformed Employee is paid by the Township for a time
period during which no duties are performed, due to vacation, holiday, illness,
incapacity, layoff, military leave, jury duty, maternity or paternity or
adoption leave, or any other approved leave of absence (as determined in the
sole discretion of the Township); provided, however, that a Nonuniformed
Employee shall not be credited for any Hours of Service for which payment is
made solely for the purpose of complying with any applicable workers'
compensation, unemployment compensation or statutory disability insurance law,
or for payment made to reimburse a Nonuniformed Employee for medical or
medically related expenses incurred by such Nonuniformed Employee.
      (3)   UNPAID ABSENCES — Each hour (not to exceed eight hours per calendar
day) for which a Nommiformed Employee is not paid by the Township for a time
period during which no duties are performed because such Nonuniformed Employee
is on an unpaid leave of absence which has been approved by the Township in
accordance with the Township's uniformly applied leave of absence policies. A
person will not receive credit for Hours of Service during an unpaid leave of
absence to the extent such person's unpaid leave of absence extends beyond the
time limit established by the Township in accordance with its uniformly applied
leave of absence policies.
      (4)   BACKPAY — Each hour not already counted under Subsection A(1) or
(2) of this definition above for which backpay to a Nonuniformed Employee is
either awarded or agreed to by the Township.
      (5)   FMLA LEAVE — Each hour of work (not to exceed eight hours per
calendar day) a Nonuniformed Employee would have completed on or after August
5, 1993, but for the fact that such Nonuniformed Employee was absent from work
due to unpaid leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, but only to
the extent required to be credited under such Act.
      (6)   MILITARY SERVICE — Subject to any stricter requirements that may be
required by applicable law [including, but not limited to, the Uniformed
Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA)], each hour of work
(not to exceed eight hours per calendar day) a Nonuniformed Employee would have
completed but for the fact that such Nonuniformed Employee was absent from work
due to a military leave of absence; provided that the Member returns to his
employment with the Township as a Nonuniformed Employee within six months after
his separation from military service. A Nonuniformed Employee shall only be
credited with Hours of Service for intervening military service if he is not
entitled to receive retirement benefits for such military service under a
retirement system administered and wholly or partially paid for by any other
governmental agency. The foregoing sentence shall not apply where a
Nonuniformed Employee is eligible to receive or is receiving military
retirement benefits earned by a combination of active duty and nonactive duty
with a reserve or national guard component of the armed forces.
   B.   Hours of Service credited under Subsection A(1) through (6) above shall
be credited to the calendar year in which the hours were worked or would have
been worked but for a leave of absence.
   JOINT AND SURVIVOR ANNUITY — A reduced monthly annuity for a Members life
with a survivor annuity which provides monthly payments to the Members Survivor
after the Member's death, equal to either 50%, 75% or 100%, at the election of
the Member, of the reduced monthly payments provided to the Member before his
death.
   LATE RETIREMENT AGE — A Member's age after Normal Retirement Age.
   LATE RETIREMENT DATE — The first day of the month coinciding with or next
following the Member's Late Retirement Age.
   LATE RETIREMENT PENSION — The late retirement benefits provided to a Member
in accordance with the terms of §
A262-7.
   MEMBER — Any Nonuniformed Employee who is a Member pursuant to §
A262-4.
   NONUNIFORMED EMPLOYEE — Any individual who is employed by the Township and
is classified by the Township as a Nonuniformed Employee.
   NONUNIFORMED PENSION BOARD — The Township of Upper Dublin Nonuniformed
Pension Plan and Pension Fund Board of Trustees, a board established by the
Board of Commissioners to administer the terms of the Pension Plan and the
Pension Fund.
   NORMAL RETIREMENT AGE — The date upon which a Member attains age 60.
   NORMAL RETIREMENT DATE — The first day of the month coinciding with or next
following the Member's Normal Retirement Age.
   NORMAL RETIREMENT PENSION — The normal retirement benefit provided to a
Member in accordance with the terms of §
A262-5.
   PENSION FUND — The trust fund established by the Township to hold and
administer the Pension Plan's assets.
   PERIOD OF EMPLOYMENT or PERIOD OF REEMPLOYMENT — Any uninterrupted period of
time during which a Nonuniformed Employee is employed by the Township as a
Nonuniformed Employee.
   PLAN ADMINISTRATOR — The person or entity that may be appointed by the
Nonuniformed Pension Board to administer the terms of the Pension Plan and the
Pension Fund on a day-to-day basis. Any such Plan Administrator shall have such
authority to administer the Pension Plan as explicitly delegated to it by the
Nonuniformed Pension Board.
   PLAN YEAR — The twelve-month period commencing each January 1 and ending the
following December 31.
   RETIRES or RETIREMENT — A Member who ceases active employment with the
township after reaching his Early Retirement Age, Normal Retirement Age or Late
Retirement Age, whichever applies.
   SALARY:
   A.   The monthly sum of the following amounts:
      (1)   All base wages paid to a Nonuniformed Employee by the Township,
including overtime, but excluding certain special payments (such as bonuses,
expense reimbursements and other types of nonperiodic compensation); plus
      (2)   Any pre-tax contributions to a Township deferred compensation plan
under Code Sections 457 or 414(h) on behalf of a Nonuniformed Employee and any
pre-tax contributions to a Code Section 125 plan; plus
      (3)   Any payments made by the Township to a Nonuniformed Employee
pursuant to the Heart and Lung Act, 53 P.S. §§ 637 and 638.
   B.   In no event shall a Member's Salary used to compute his Average Monthly
Salary exceed $160,000 for the 1997 Plan Year, and for all Plan Years after
1997, shall not exceed the compensation limit set forth in Code Section 401 (a)
(17), as adjusted for cost-of-living increases.
   SINGLE LIFE, ANNUITY — An annuity providing monthly payments for a Member's
life with all benefits ceasing upon such Member's death.
   SURVIVOR:
   A.   For the purpose of Death Benefits under the Pension Plan:
      (1)   The surviving spouse of a Member;
      (2)   If no surviving spouse, the Members surviving minor children, with
such minor children sharing equally in any benefits provided under the Pension
Plan if there is more than one child; or
      (3)   The individual(s) designated by the Member in accordance with the
procedures established and uniformly applied by the Nonuniformed Pension Board
or the Plan Administrator, if applicable.
   B.   "Survivor" means, for the purpose of determining annuity payments for a
Fixed Period Single Life Annuity or a Joint and Survivor Annuity, the
individual designated by the Member at the time he elects the form of his
payment under Article VII.
   TOWNSHIP — The Township of Upper Dublin.
   YEAR OF SERVICE — Any calendar year in which a Nonuniformed Employee earns
1,000 or more Hours of Service.
ARTICLE III
Membership
§ A262-4. Provisions for Membership.
Nonuniformed Employees shall become Members in the Plan in accordance with the
following provisions:
   A.   Continuing Members. Each Nonuniformed Employee who was a Member in the
Plan before the Effective Date shall continue to be a Member on and after the
Effective Date while a Nonuniformed Employee.
   B.   New Members. Each Nonuniformed Employee not covered under Subsection A
above shall become a Member in the Plan as of the last day of the Plan Year
immediately following his date of hire.
   C.   Reemployment of former Members. Any Member who Retires or terminates
employment with the Township, or transfers to a class of employment not covered
under the terms of the Pension Plan, and later resumes employment as a
Nonuniformed Employee of the Township shall again become a Member as of the
last day of the Plan Year following his date of rehire or reinstatement as a
Nonuniformed Employee.
ARTICLE IV
Retirement Benefits
§ A262-5. Normal Retirement Pension.
A Member who Retires upon attaining his Normal Retirement Age shall receive a
monthly amount of retirement income commencing as of his Normal Retirement Date
in an amount equal to his Accrued Pension determined as of the Member's Normal
Retirement Date, subject to the forms of payment and election requirements
discussed in Article VII.
§ A262-6. Early Retirement Pension.
A Member who Retires on or after Early Retirement Age, but before Normal
Retirement Age, shall receive a monthly amount of retirement income:
   A.   Commencing as of the Member's Normal Retirement Date in an amount equal
to the Member's Accrued Pension determined as of the Member's Early Retirement
Date, subject to the forms of payment and election requirements discussed in
Article VII; or
   B.   At the Member's election, as of the Member's Early Retirement Date, or
the first day of any month thereafter prior to the Member's Normal Retirement
Date, in an amount equal to the Member's Accrued Pension determined as of the
Members Early Retirement Date, reduced by 1/2 of 1% for each calendar month by
which the Member's Benefit Commencement Date precedes the Members Normal
Retirement Date, subject to the forms of payment and election requirements
discussed in Article VII.
§ A262-7. Late Retirement Pension.
A Member who Retires on or after Late Retirement Age shall receive a monthly
amount of retirement income commencing as of the Member's Late Retirement Date
in an amount equal to the greater of his Accrued Pension determined as of the
Member's Late Retirement Date; or the Actuarial Equivalent of the Accrued
Pension calculated as of the Member's Normal Retirement Date, subject to the
forms of payment and election requirements discussed in Article VII.
§ A262-8. Benefits upon reemployment.
A Member who is reemployed by the Township as a Nonuniformed Employee shall be
subject to the following provisions:
   A.   No suspension of payments. If a Member is reemployed after a Benefit
Commencement Date, the Member's monthly benefit payments shall continue
uninterrupted during the Period of Reemployment.
   B.   Retention or Loss of prior Years of Service for vesting purposes.
Subject to Subsection C below, if a Member is reemployed by the Township as a
Nonuniformed Employee within two years, whether before or after a Benefit
Commencement Date, the Member's Years of Service attributable to the prior
Period of Employment will be aggregated with the Member's Years of Service
attributable to the Period of Reemployment for purposes of determining the
Member's vested interest under §
A262-11 and Years of Service for determining the Member's Early or Normal
Retirement Age, with respect to the benefits payable to the Member upon
subsequent termination of employment or Retirement. Otherwise, the Member's
Years of Service attributable to the prior Period of Employment shall be
disregarded.
   C.   Form of Payment. Years of Service attributable to a Period of
Employment for which a Member has received, or is deemed to have received, a
distribution pursuant to §
A262-17 shall not be taken into account for any purpose following a Member's
reemployment with the Township. Except with respect to a payment under §
A262-17, the form of payment in effect for the Member on the Benefit
Commencement Date prior to reemployment, if applicable, shall apply to all
future benefits payable from the Pension Plan to the Member.
   D.   Calculation of benefit upon termination or Retirement after
reemployment. A Member's benefit following termination or Retirement after
Reemployment shall equal the sum of:
      (1)   The pension being paid to the Member; plus
      (2)   The pension attributable to any increase in the Member's vested
percentage in the pension based on the Member's prior Period of Employment,
determined as of the Benefit Commencement Date for the pension attributable to
the Period of Reemployment under Subsection D(3) below, determined under the
same provision of Article VI or VII as applied to the prior pension; plus
      (3)   The pension attributable to the Period of Reemployment, determined
under Article VI or VII as of the subsequent Benefit Commencement Date as if
the Period of Employment had been the Member's only employment with the
Township, subject to Subsection C above in regard to aggregating Years of
Service for vesting and determining Early Retirement Age and Normal Retirement
Age; provided that the pension attributable to the Period of Reemployment shall
be offset by the Actuarial Equivalent of any prior distributions made to a
Member pursuant to §
A262-15C of
A262-17.
§ A262-9. Maximum benefit payments.
Notwithstanding any other provision of the Pension Plan to the contrary, a
Member's annual benefit, together with the Member's annual benefit under any
other plan(s) required to be aggregated with the Pension Plan under Code
Section 415, may not exceed the annual limitations on benefits imposed by Code
Section 415. In the event that the Code Section 415 limitations are exceeded in
any calendar year for a Member, such Member's benefits shall be reduced under
this Pension Plan to the extent necessary to satisfy the applicable Code
Section 415 annual limitations. If a Member's benefits are reduced under the
Pension Plan to satisfy the limitations of Code Section 415 and the Code
Section 415 limitations are subsequently increased, such Member's benefits also
shall be increased to the extent permitted under the increased Code Section 415
limitations.
ARTICLE V
Vesting and Benefits Upon Termination of Employment
§ A262-10. Benefits upon termination of employment.
A member who terminates employment with the Township and is not eligible for a
benefit under Article IV shall receive a monthly amount of retirement income:
   A.   Commencing as of the Member's Normal Retirement Date in an amount equal
to the Members Accrued Pension determined as of the Members employment
termination date as vested in accordance with §
A262-11, subject to the forms of payment and election requirements discussed in
Article VII; or
   B.   At the Member's election, if the Member has at least 10 Years of
Service, commencing as of the Member's Early Retirement Date, or the first day
of any month thereafter prior to the Member's Normal Retirement Date, in an
amount equal to the Member's Accrued Pension determined as of the Member's
employment termination date, reduced by V2 of 1% for each calendar month by
which the Member's Benefit Commencement Date precedes the Member's No,. mai
Retirement Date, subject to the forms of payment and election requirements
discussed in Article VII.
§ A262-11. Vesting schedule.
   A.   A Member's Accrued Pension shall vest in accordance with the following
schedule:
Years of Service Vesting Percentage
Years of Service Vesting Percentage
3 or less        0%
4                40%
5                50%
6                60%
7                70%
8                80%
9                90%
10 or more       100%
 
   B.   Notwithstanding the vesting schedule set forth above, a Member who
terminates employment with the Township because of death or Retirement shall be
fully vested in his Accrued Benefit.
§ A262-12. Forfeitures.
A Member shall forfeit the nonvested portion of his Accrued Pension as of the
end of the Plan Year following his termination of employment.
ARTICLE VI
Death Benefit
§ A262-13. Death Benefit.
The Survivor of a Member, if any, who dies before the Member's Benefit
Commencement Date shall receive a Death Benefit under the Pension Plan in an
amount equal to the Actuarial Equivalent of such Member's vested Accrued
Pension. The Death Benefit, if any, for the Survivor of a Member who dies after
a Benefit Commencement Date shall be determined in accordance with Article VII,
based upon the applicable form of payments of the Member's pension.
ARTICLE VII
Payment of Benefits Upon Retirement, Death or Other Termination of Employment
§ A262-14. Normal form of benefit payments.
Unless §
A262-17 applies or the Member elects an optional form of payment as described
under §
A262-15 below, the normal form of payment of a pension to the Member is a Fixed
Period Single Life Annuity for a period of 10 years.
§ A262-15. Optional forms of benefit payments.
A Member may elect, in accordance with §
A262-16 below, to have his benefit adjusted to the Actuarial Equivalent of the
normal form under §
A262-14 and paid to him in one of the following optional forms:
   A.   A Single Life Annuity.
   B.   A Joint and Survivor Annuity.
   C.   A single lump sum.
§ A262-16. Application for benefit payments.
Except as otherwise provided under §§
A262-17 and
A262-18 below, benefit payments under the Pension Plan will not commence until
a Member has completed an application form in accordance with the uniform
procedures established by the Nonuniformed Pension Board or the Plan
Administrator, if applicable. After a Member commences receipt of benefit
payments under the Pension Plan, the Member shall not be permitted to elect a
different form of payment at a later date.
§ A262-17. Small benefit cash-out.
Notwithstanding any other provision of the Plan to the contrary, if the
Actuarial Equivalent lump sum value of a Member's vested Accrued Pension is
$5,000 or less as of the Member's Benefit Commencement Date, payment shall be
made in a single lump sum (or deemed to have been made in a single lump sum if
zero) as soon as administratively practicable following his termination of
employment; provided that a Member shall have the opportunity to elect a Direct
Rollover of such lump sum payment in accordance with §
A262-19 below.
§ A262-18. Payment of Death Benefits.
As soon as administratively practicable after a Member's death, the Actuarial
Equivalent lump sum value of the Member's Death Benefit shall be paid to the
Member's Survivor in a single lump sum payment; provided that, if the Member's
Survivor is the Member's spouse, such Member's spouse shall have the
opportunity to elect a Direct Rollover of such lump sum payment in accordance
with §
A262-19 below.
§ A262-19. Direct rollovers.
A Member or a Member's spouse may elect a Direct Rollover of lump sum payments
distributed under the Pension Plan pursuant to §§
A262-15C,
A262-17 and
A262-18 above. Any such Direct Rollover shall be made in accordance with the
requirements of Code Section 401 (a)(31).
§ A262-20. Required Distribution of Benefits.
Notwithstanding any other provision of the Pension Plan to the contrary,
distribution of a Member's benefits under the Pension Plan shall commence no
later than April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year in which
the Member attains age 701/2 or retires, whichever is later. Distributions made
pursuant to this §
A262-20 shall not be eligible for Direct Rollover.
ARTICLE VIII
Members' Required Contributions
[Amended 1-9-2001 by Ord. No. 1055]
§ A262-21. Required contributions.
"Required contributions" means the total amount of contributions each Member is
required to contribute to the Pension Fund under this Pension Plan.
§ A262-21.1. Amount.
Effective January 1, 2002, employees shall contribute 1% of their gross monthly
wages to the Township Pension Plan. These contributions shall be made by
payroll deduction on a per pay basis.
§ A262-21.2. Refund of required contributions.
   A.   Any Member who, for any reason whatsoever, shall be ineligible to
receive pension benefits under this Pension Plan shall be entitled to a refund
of any required contributions he made to the Pension Fund when the Member
discontinues his employment with the Township.
   B.   Amount of refund. All refunds pursuant to Subsection A shall be equal
to the total amount of a Member's required contributions contributed pursuant
to §
A262-21.1 plus the prorated amount of the net interest earned by the Member's
required contributions while in the Pension Fund.
   C.   Form of payment. All refunds of required contributions shall be in the
form of a single lump sum payment.
   D.   Death of Member. If a Member's discontinuance of employment with the
Township is due to the Member's death, any refund of required contributions
shall be paid to the deceased Member's designated beneficiary or, in the
absence thereof, to his estate.
   E.   Termination of Pension Plan or Complete Discontinuance of required
contributions. In the event that the Pension Plan is terminated pursuant to
state law, the right of each Member to his required contributions shall be
nonforfeitable. The nonforfeitable amount of each Member's required
contributions shall be the amount described in Subsection B. Members shall be
entitled to receive their nonforfeitable required contributions in accordance
with the terms of the Pension Plan.
ARTICLE IX
Maintenance of Pension Fund
§ A262-22. Types of contributions.
   A.   The Pension Fund shall be maintained through the following types of
contributions:
      (1)   Payments made by the Commonwealth Treasurer to the Township
Treasurer from moneys received pursuant to Act 205 2 and allocated for benefits
for Members.
      (2)   Annual appropriations to the Pension Fund made by the Township.
      (3)   Any other contributions made to the Pension Plan in accordance with
applicable law.
   B.   All payments described in this §
A262-22 shall be part of the Pension Fund and shall not be applied to any other
pension fund or account or disbursed in any manner, except as provided herein.
2 Editor's Note: See 53 P.S. § 895.101 et seq.
§ A262-23. Pension Fund sole source of Pension Plan benefits.
The obligation to make payments for pension benefits under the Pension Plan
shall be a charge only upon the Pension Fund and not upon other moneys or funds
of the Township.
§ A262-24. Payments from Commonwealth Treasurer.
The annual payment made by the Commonwealth Treasurer to the Township Treasurer
pursuant to Act 205 3 for benefits under the Pension Plan shall be used to
reduce the Pension Plan's annual normal cost as defined in Section 102 of Act
205 4 and described under §
A262-25 below.
3 Editor's Note: See 53 P.S. § 895.101 et seq.
4 Editor's Note: See 53 P.S. § 895.102.
§ A262-25. Normal cost.
   A.   The Pension Plan's normal cost is comprised of the following amounts:
      (1)   The unfunded liability of the Pension Plan. The "unfunded
liability" means the present value of the unfunded pension benefits accrued
under the Pension Plan during all years prior to the current year. The unfunded
liability of the Pension Plan shall be amortized over 25 years.
      (2)   The future service liability of the Pension Plan. The "future
service liability" means the present value of pension benefits accrued during
the current year.
      (3)   Administrative costs. Each year the management and administration
of the Pension Plan and the Pension Fund result in certain administrative
costs. Only administrative costs which meet the following criteria are
allowable as part of the Pension Plan's normal cost:
         (a)   The administrative costs are directly associated with the
Pension Plan.
         (b)   The Nonuniformed Pension Board monitors the services provided to
ensure that the administrative costs are necessary, reasonable and beneficial
for the Pension Plan and Pension Fund.
         (c)   Appropriate records of the administrative costs are kept as
necessary for the Auditor General audit.
   B.   Any administrative costs that do not satisfy the criteria described
above shall be provided for by appropriation made by the Board of
Commissioners.
ARTICLE X
Administration of Pension Plan
§ A262-26. Administrative provisions.
The Pension Plan shall be administered in accordance with the provisions of
Chapter 35, Article II, of the Upper Dublin Township Code as amended by
Ordinance No. 939.
§ A262-27. Powers of Nonuniformed Pension Board.
To the extent not otherwise inconsistent with the terms of
Chapter 35, Article II, of the Upper Dublin Township Code, the Nonuniformed
Pension Board and the Plan Administrator, if applicable, shall have the full
discretionary authority to determine all questions arising in connection with
the administration, interpretation and application of the Pension Plan,
including, without limitation, the full discretionary authority to determine
any claims for benefits under the Pension Plan. The Nonuniformed Pension
Board's powers include, but are not limited to, the full discretionary
authority to:
   A.   Prescribe rules for the operation of the Pension Plan.
   B.   Determine all questions (including any and all questions of fact)
affecting eligibility to participate in and receive benefits under the Pension
Plan.
   C.   Prepare and distribute communications to Nonuniformed Employees as a
part of Pension Plan operations.
   D.   Prescribe forms to facilitate the operation of the Pension Plan.
   E.   Construe and interpret the terms of the Pension Plan, including the
power to remedy possible ambiguities, inconsistencies or omissions.
   F.   Determine the amount of benefits and authorize payments from Pension
Fund assets.
   G.   Obtain from the Township and from Nonuniformed Employees and former
Nonuniformed Employees such information as may be necessary or appropriate to
administer the Pension Plan.
   H.   Maintain Pension Plan records.
   I.   Litigate, settle claims and respond to and comply with court
proceedings and orders on the Pension Plan's behalf.
   J.   Enter into contracts on the Pension Plan's behalf.
   K.   Exercise all other powers given to the Nonuniformed Pension Board as
may be delegated to it by the Board of Commissioners.
§ A262-28. Duties of the Nonuniformed Pension Board.
The Nonuniformed Pension Board shall administer the Pension Plan and adopt such
rules and regulations as are necessary or advisable to implement and administer
the Pension Plan and to transact its business.
§ A262-29. Finality of Nonuniformed Pension Board decisions.
The Nonuniformed Pension Board shall exercise its powers hereunder in a uniform
and nondiscriminatory manner Any and all disputes with respect to the Pension
Plan which may arise shall be referred to the Nonuniformed Pension Board, and
its decision shall be final, conclusive and binding. Furthermore, if any
question arises as to the meaning, interpretation or application of any
provision hereof, the decision of the Nonuniformed Pension Board with respect
thereto shall be final and conclusive.
ARTICLE XI
Miscellaneous
§ A262-30. Payments to be free from all claims.
No benefits payable under the Pension Plan shall be subject to the debts or
liabilities of a Member or a Survivor, and any attempt to alienate, sell,
transfer, assign, pledge or otherwise encumber any such benefit, whether
presently or thereafter payable, shall be void, and no benefit under the
Pension Plan shall be subject in any manner to attachment, garnishment or
encumbrance of any kind.
§ A262-31. Incompetency; minors.
Every person receiving or claiming benefits under the Pension Plan shall be
conclusively presumed to be mentally competent and of age until the date on
which the Nonuniformed Pension Board receives a written notice, in a form and
manner acceptable to the Nonuniformed Pension Board, that such person is
incompetent or a minor, for whom a guardian or other person legally vested with
the care of the person or estate has been appointed. However, if the
Nonuniformed Pension Board finds that any person to whom a benefit is payable
under the Pension Plan is unable to care for his or her affairs because of
incompetency, or is a minor, any payment due (unless a prior claim therefor
shall have been made by a duly appointed legal representative) may be paid to
the spouse, a child, a parent or other person who is eligible to receive
payment from the Pension Plan for the account of such person. To the extent
permitted by law, any such payment so made shall be a complete discharge of any
liability therefor under the Pension Plan.
§ A262-32. Missing persons.
If the Nonuniformed Pension Board is unable to make payment because the
identity or whereabouts of a Member or his Survivor(s) is unknown, the Member's
Accrued Pension shall be forfeited and all further benefits with respect to
such person shall be discontinued, and all liability for the payment thereof
shall terminate. In the event of the subsequent reappearance of the Member or
his Survivor prior to termination of the Pension Plan, the benefits which were
due and payable and which such person missed shall be paid in a single sum, and
any future benefits due such person shall be reinstated in full. The amount
payable to such person shall be equal to the benefit forfeited, without
interest on such amount for the period commencing on the date such benefit was
forfeited and ending on the date of the claim.
§ A262-33. Amendment and termination.
The Pension Plan and Pension Fund established herein may be discontinued,
modified, altered, terminated or repealed according to law, through an
appropriate ordinance or resolutions adopted by the Board of Commissioners;
provided, however, that any such amendment or action shall not reduce the
vested rights of any Member in his benefits under the Pension Plan. In the
event that the Board of Commissioners terminates the Pension Plan or otherwise
causes the discontinuance of contributions to the Pension Plan, all Members
(including both actively employed Members and terminated Members entitled to,
or receiving, benefits under the Pension Plan), to the extent not vested, shall
become fully vested in their Accrued Pensions upon the occurrence of any such
event.
§ A262-34. Employment rights.
Nothing contained in the Pension Plan or any modification of the Pension Plan
shall be construed as a guaranty of employment or shall enlarge, diminish or
otherwise affect a Nonuniformed Employee's right, or lack thereof, with respect
to his or her employment with the Township.
§ A262-35. Severability.
In the event that any provision of the Pension Plan shall be held illegal or
invalid for any reason, such illegality or invalidity shall not affect the
remaining parts of this Pension Plan, and it shall be construed and enforced as
if such illegal or invalid provision had never been included.
§ A262-36. Applicable law.
Except to the extent superseded or preempted by federal law, the Pension Plan
and all rights hereunder shall be governed, construed and administered in
accordance with the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
§ A262-37. Gender and number. 5
As used in the Pension Plan, the masculine shall include the feminine, and the
feminine shall include the masculine; and the use of the singular shall include
the use of the plural, and the use of the plural shall include the use of the
singular.
5 Editor's Note: See also Art. II, Definitions.
Chapter A263
SHADE TREE COMMISSION RULES AND REGULATIONS
§
A263-1.   Shade Tree Commission operating procedures.
§
A263-2.   Tree trimming and removal operations.
§
A263-3.   Enforcement.
[HISTORY: Adopted by the Shade Tree Commission 8-2-2001. These regulations were
approved by the Board of Commissioners 4-9-2002. Amendments noted where
applicable.]
GENERAL REFERENCES
 
Shade trees — See
Ch. 195.
§ A263-1. Shade Tree Commission operating procedures.
   A.   Organization; quorum.
      (1)   The Shade Tree Commission (STC) shall organize at its first
regularly scheduled meeting in each calendar year by the election of one of its
members to serve as Chairperson, one as Vice Chairperson and one as Secretary.
The Vice Chairperson and the Secretary may be the same person.
      (2)   Three members of the STC shall constitute a quorum, and no action
of the STC shall be valid unless it shall have the concurrence of at least two
members.
   B.   Duties of officers.
      (1)   The Chairperson or, in his or her absence, the Vice Chairperson
shall preside at all meetings and hearings of the STC, decide all points of
order or procedure and perform any duties required by law or these rules and
regulations.
      (2)   The Secretary shall carry on at the direction of the STC all
official correspondence of the STC, send out all notices required by law and
these rules and regulations, keep a record of each official action of the STC
and perform all other duties required by law or these rules and regulations.
Any other STC Commissioner may likewise issue correspondence on behalf of the
STC if directed by the Chairperson, the Vice Chairperson or the STC to do so.
   C.   Meetings. All meetings shall be held either at the call of the
Chairperson or at the call of two members of the STC. All meetings of the STC
shall be held in compliance with the Sunshine Act (53 Pa.C.S.A. §§ 701 through
716). The Secretary of the STC shall give the Township Manager and each member
of the STC no less than 24 hours' notice of each and every meeting of the STC.
   D.   Administrative assistance. The Board of Commissioners may approve such
administrative assistance as may be necessary for the STC to fulfill its
duties. In addition, the STC may request the assistance of such other
consultants or experts as it deems necessary.
   E.   Amendment of rules and regulations. The STC may amend, revise, void or
replace these rules and regulations for any reason by action of a majority of
the STC at any properly convened meeting of the STC. Before any changes to
these rules and regulations become effective, those changes must be reviewed by
the Township Manager, approved by the Township Board of Commissioners and
advertised twice in a newspaper in general circulation in the Township. These
rules and regulations and any amendments thereto shall be made available to the
public for distribution or inspection.
§ A263-2. Tree trimming and removal operations.
   A.   Statement of policy.
      (1)   Severe tree trimming poses a significant threat to the health of
street trees in the Township, endangers the welfare and property of those using
public rights-of-way and creates adverse aesthetic effects which denigrate the
quality of life in the community and negatively impact property values.
      (2)   Healthful trees constituting the urban forest can aid in the
conservation of vital energy resources and natural resources in the Township.
      (3)   Healthful trees are a valuable amenity to the urban environment,
creating greater human comfort by providing shade, cooling the air through
evaporation, restoring oxygen to the atmosphere, reducing glare, reducing noise
levels, providing an ecological habitat for songbirds and other animal and
plant species, providing for more effective transitions between different land
uses and breaking the monotony of urbanized development.
      (4)   While it is recognized that the public rights-of-way are shared by
the Township, the traveling public, the owners of adjacent properties, public
utility companies and others using them with permission, it is the Shade Tree
Commissiou's obligation to assure that all using the public rights-of-way do so
in a manner which respects, preserves and enhances that portion of the urban
forest made up of street trees growing within or adjacent to such rights-of-
way.
      (5)   The most effective way the Shade Tree Commission can fulfill its
obligation is to carefully regulate the activities of those using the public
rights-of-way and to assure that they do so responsibly by the promulgation and
enforcement of these regulations.
   B.   Permits.
      (1)   Any person or entity seeking to cut, trim, prune or remove all or
part of any tree in the public right-of-way shall first apply for and receive a
permit therefore from the STC. The application fee shall be $10 per tree or
$500 for a blanket permit. Applications shall be submitted on a form available
from the Secretary of the STC and from the Township Director of Public Works.
The Secretary may reject any application which is not accompanied by all of the
information requested on the form.
      (2)   No permit shall be required to remove all or part of any tree
constituting an immediate hazard to life or property or to those using or
occupying the public-right-of-way or where such removal is necessitated by
reason of damage to the tree from storm, wind, earthquake, fire or accident.
The STC may waive the requirement for a permit in cases of hardship or where
the public interest requires.
      (3)   Permits may be granted outright or granted subject to conditions
consistent with the provisions of the Township Code and these regulations.
Unless specifically set forth on the permit, no permit shall be valid for a
period greater than 90 days after the date of its issuance. No permit shall be
granted unless the following minimum conditions are met (in all cases where the
STC is referenced, that shall be taken to mean the STC, or its authorized
representative):
         (a)   The STC has determined that there is a need for the proposed
work on the tree; and
         (b)   The STC is satisfied that the persons who are to perform the
work are qualified to do so, although the issuance of the permit shall not be
construed as a warranty of the qualifications of such person; and
         (c)   The STC has determined that any potential detriment to the
Township tree population entailed by the proposed work is justified in the
individual case. In making this determination, the STC shall consider factors
such as the probability that the proposed work will destroy or seriously injure
the tree, the tree's health, the desirability of that species as a street tree,
whether the tree's condition and size threaten serious damage to life or
property, the condition and number of other street trees in the vicinity and
whether there are other less onerous means of accomplishing the applicant's
goals, and other criteria derived from the application of the policy statement
set forth hereinabove to the individual application.
      (4)   The STC may condition any permit granted for the removal of a shade
tree on the permitee replacing the tree with one of a size and specie approved
by the STC. The cost of removal and the cost of replacemeut, if required, shall
be borne by the permitee.
      (5)   No work pursuant to a permit may be performed where the permitee is
not the owner of the property adjacent to the public right-of-way where the
work is to performed unless a sign has been posted in a prominent location
adjacent to the work site and visible from the public right-of-way for a period
of not less than five days beforehand. Where work is to be performed on or
adjacent to several properties in the same block, only one sign per block must
be posted. The sign must state that tree trimming work is to be performed, the
approximate date when it will be performed, the name of the entity performing
it or on whose behalf it is being performed and a telephone number where
interested parties may call a representative of the permitee to discuss the
work. In lieu of such a sign, the permitee may provide the owners of property
abutting the work with actual written notice, containing this same information,
no less than five days beforehand A copy of the notice, when posted or written,
shall be forwarded to the STC and the Township Manager.
      (6)   Public utility companies subject to the jurisdiction of the
Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission (PUC) are subject to this permitting
requirement. Utilities may apply for a blanket permit to prune around utility
lines, the fee for which shall be $500. Public utilities may perform such
pruning as is necessary to comply with the safety regulations of the PUC and to
maintain a safe operation of their facilities, provided they shall comply with
the provisions of these regulations, including the notification provisions and
the specific pruning standards set forth herein. The Shade Tree Commission will
modify such specific pruning standards, upon application, where the public
utility company demonstrates to its satisfaction that such pruning standards
will not permit it to comply with the PUC's safety regulations for a period of
three years of normal tree growth following completion of such pruning.
   C.   Trimming standards. The primary aim of trimming is to preserve the
health, beauty and longevity of trees Trimming for such purpose will also make
trees safer, more functional and valuable. Practices such as stub cuts, random
branch removal and topping (stubbing back the entire crown) defeat the primary
aim, create hazards and drastically reduce the monetary value of trees.
Therefore, such practices shall not be employed. The following standards
identify trimming methods which will give maximum benefits to both trees and
people and must be employed when trimming and pruning within the public right-
of-way:
      (1)   Types of cuts.
         (a)   Removal of laterals.
            [1]   Shoulder cuts. The final cut in removing a lateral branch
should be immediately beyond the branch bark ridges, preserving the branch
collar. Do not make stub cuts (an inch or more beyond the branch collar). Do
not make flush cuts (through the branch collar).
            [2]   Triple cuts. For any branch too large to be held while being
cut, remove by means of the following cuts:
               [a]   Undercut the branch four inches to 10 inches beyond the
base.
               [b]   Cut off the branch beyond the undercut.
               [c]   Remove the remaining stub via a shoulder cut as described
above.
         (b)   Removal of terminals (tip thinning and drop crotching).
            [1]   Thinning "Lace out" the terminal portions of branches by
cutting the terminals back to the laterals. (The basal diameter of the
remaining lateral should be V3 the diameter of the terminal being removed.)
Remove numerous small terminals and laterals rather than taking out a few large
ones.
            [2]   Size reduction. To take out portions of the crown for
reducing height, remove the terminals back to the laterals. Each lateral should
be suitably situated to serve as the new terminal, thus establishing the crown
at a lower level. The basal diameter of a lateral should be at least 1/3 the
basal diameter of the terminal being removed. (Laterals smaller than this
cannot function effectively as new terminals, and the effect is then similar to
a stub cut.)
      (2)   Pruning functions. Not all of the following procedures will apply
to any one tree, and two or more may be performed more or less simultaneously.
In most cases, however, trimming done in the following general sequence will be
more efficient and will help avoid unnecessary trimming.
         (a)   As a rule, not more than 1/4 of the total foliage mass should be
removed at one trimming. Exceptions are:
            [1]   Extreme thinning of heavy crowns of brittle trees, and
            [2]   Severe thinning of crowns to prevent blow-down when root
pruning is done.
         (b)   Remove branches as needed and redirect new growth to clear
utility lines, pedestrian and vehicular traffic areas, buildings, streetlights,
walls and other objects, as well as trees and shrubs. Do not make stub cuts. Do
not cut terminals back to very small laterals. Retain a screen effect as much
as possible.
         (c)   Remove dead, broken, diseased or markedly unthrifty brauches.
         (d)   Remove crossing branches and those which will become crossing
branches (such as suckers, water sprouts and branches growing vigorously into
the interior of the crown).
         (e)   Remove sharp-angled branches. Remove most branches arising at
angles of less than 30°, with the exception of species which fuse at branch
bases. If a narrow- angled branch needs to be retained for the sake of form, it
should be lightened and restricted in growth to reduce the danger of wind
breakage.
         (f)   Remove parallel branches. If two branches within a foot or so of
each other run parallel for several feet along their main stems, the less
desirable one should be taken out.
         (g)   Trim for balance and form. To maintain the natural shape, if a
tree grows in an unbalanced manner which is atypical and unattractive, or which
poses a potential hazard, remove such branches as may need to be eliminated to
restore more typical form or to minimize the perceived hazard.
         (h)   Trim to reduce wind resistance. If a tree is shallow rooted or
has a high or heavily foliaged crown, such that it is susceptible to blow-down
or limb breakage in high winds, trim more frequently. It does not call for
topping; beheading tall or dense trees ruins their form and vitality and
intensifies wind hazards in subsequent years. This type of thinning should be
done by removing a large number of small branches rather than a few large
branches. The end effect should maintain most of the original form, but with a
lacy openness.
         (i)   Exceptions. The STC may approve trimming trees in a manner not
typical of the natural form of the tree specie. Such approval shall be based
upon a finding that the resulting shape is necessary for the public health and
safety or the health and safety of the tree.
      (3)   Severe tree trimming is prohibited. "Severely trimmed" shall mean
the cutting of the branches and/or trunk of a tree in a manner which will
substantially reduce the overall size of the tree area so as to destroy the
existing symmetrical appearance or natural shape of the tree in a manner which
results in the removal of main lateral branches leaving the trunk of the tree
in a stub appearance.
      (4)   Other prohibited activities. Those activities set forth in the
Upper Dublin Township Code, §
195-10, are considered prohibited activities, and, in addition, the following:
         (a)   Damaging or cutting the roots of a shade tree;
         (b)   Anchoring heavy equipment to a shade tree;
         (c)   Dropping or lowering any object or tree section through the
canopy of a shade tree, except such as are securely fastened to ropes to
control damage.
      (5)   Utility line clearance standards. The STC recognizes that public
utilities provide a service to the public, that such service should not be
subject to interruption, and that the trimming of street trees is necessary to
forestall such interruption. The STC also recognizes that public utilities can
trim street trees and accomplish the utility's goals while adhering to the
standards set forth in these regulations. It is expected that public utilities
will maintain a schedule of line clearance that will minimize interruptions
while at the same time minimizing the clearance distances required from tree
branches. It is the STC's view that repeating line clearance activities no less
frequently than every three years is a reasonable expectation, and that the
clearances set forth on the following chart represent an appropriate
accommodation to the needs of public utilities if such a schedule is adhered
to. Pruning to accomplish greater line clearances than are set forth below will
be considered a violation of these regulations (Note: all measurements are in
feet):
 
Rate of Tree All Public Utilities 13.2 KV Electric Line 34 KV Electric Line
Growth       Over Side Under      Over Side Under       Over Side Under
Fast         6    6    6          8    8    8           10   8    8
Medium       6    4    4          8    6    6           10   6    6
Slow         6    4    4          8    4    4           10   4    4
Compatible   4    2    2          4    3    3           6    3    3
 
§ A263-3. Enforcement.
   A.   The STC will consider a violation of the trimming and removal standards
set forth in these regulations to constitute a public nuisance. Upon finding
that any person or entity has caused such a violation, the STC shall give
notice to the violator to immediately cease and desist from further violations.
If the nature of the violation is that a tree has been severely trimmed, the
permit or, in the case of a public utility, the privilege to trim in the public
right-of-way shall immediately be suspended until such time as the violator
removes the damaged tree and replaces it with a suitable species of comparable
maturity, or as nearly so as reasonably possible. The STC, in its sole
discretion, and in lieu of the violator replacing the damaged tree, can accept
from the violator the payment of a sum of money which the STC determines to be
required to accomplish the same purpose, plus an additional payment of 10% for
administration expenses.
   B.   The STC reserves the right to seek such further legal and equitable
remedies as it deems appropriate to remedy the violation and/or to prevent
further violations.
   C.   Any person or entity objecting to an enforcement decision or action of
the STC, including the STC's determination of the cost of replacement of any
tree, may, within 30 days of receipt of notice from the STC, appeal to the
Board of Commissioners which shall hold a hearing thereon within 30 days and
promptly render a decision.

Chapter A265
FEE SCHEDULE
§
A265-1.   Schedule of fees.
[HISTORY: Adopted by the Board of Commissioners of the Township of Upper Dublin
7-9-2024 by Ord. No. 24-1392.]
§ A265-1.   Schedule of fees.
The following schedule consists of a compilation and consolidation of
provisions pertaining to fees for the various applications, licenses and
permits required or provided for under Township ordinances, rules and
regulations as included in this Code. This schedule continues in effect the fee
provisions existing in the various ordinances of the Township. To the extent
there is a conflict between this fee schedule and any other fee charged in
Township ordinances, this schedule shall control. Specific regulations,
application procedures and requirements, conditions and approval provisions
with respect to which each fee is required may be found in the pertinent
chapter of this Code. This fee schedule may be altered from time to time by
Resolution of the Board of Commissioners.
   FEE SCHEDULE INDEX
   
SECTION I
   Administration
1.   Printed Paper Copies
2.   Professional Staff Review & Inspection
3.   Realty Tax Certification
4.   Right-To-Know Requests
5.   Liquor License Transfer
6.   Miscellaneous
   
SECTION II
   Building Construction
1.   Adjunct Fees
2.   Additions
3.   Alterations & Repairs
4.   Demolition
5.   Electrical Wiring & Equipment
6.   HVAC/Mechanical & Fuel Appliances
7.   New Buildings
8.   Plumbing & Sewer
9.   Property Transfer Certification (Point-of-Sale/Resale)
10.   Miscellaneous Applications, Permits, & Fees
   
SECTION III
   Engineering
1.   Grading/Excavation
2.   Stormwater Management
3.   Watercourses
   
SECTION IV
   Fire Services
1.   Fire Protection Permits
2.   Fire Safety Inspection
3.   Fire Investigative Records
4.   Housing
5.   Miscellaneous
   
SECTION V
   Police Department
1.   Peddling & Solicitation
2.   Records & Reports
3.   Special Duty
4.   Vehicle Towing
   
SECTION VI
   Parks & Recreation
1.   Cancellations, Infractions, & Security Deposits
2.   Community Pool Passes
3.   Dog Park Access
4.   Facility Rentals
5.   Park Amenities & Dedications
6.   Staff Fees
   
SECTION VII
   Public Works
1.   Highway Occupancy Permits (HOP)
2.   Sanitation
   
SECTION VIII
   Zoning, Subdivision & Land Development
1.   Hearing Applications
2.   Subdivision & Land Development
3.   Miscellaneous
SECTION I: ADMINISTRATION
 
1. Printed Paper Copies       Fees
 a. Black & White Copies*     
  i.   First 1,000 pages Up to $0.25 per copy
  ii.   Beyond 1,000 pageUp to $0.20 per copy
 b. Color Copies**           Up to $0.50 per copy
 c. Specialized Documents*** Up to actual cost
 
*A "copy" is either a single-sided copy, or one side of a double-sided copy, on
8.5"x11" or 8.5"x14" paper.
**A "copy" is either a single-sided copy, or one side of a double-sided copy,
on 8.5"x11" or 8.5"x14" paper.
***Including, but not necessarily limited to, non-standard sized documents and
blueprints. Printing of plans and blueprints are billed as a pass-through cost
and pricing is dependent on current vendor cost.
2. Professional Staff Review & Inspection Fees
2. Professional Staff Review & Inspection Fees
Professional staff review and inspection fees. Engineer and professional
staff review and inspection fees for plan reviews and inspection services, as
established by the Board of Commissioners by resolution, will be charged as
set forth herein.
 a. Township Engineer                    $106 per hour
 b. Fire Marshal                         $86 per hour
 c. Public Works Director                $90 per hour
 d. Code Enforcement Director            $86 per hour
 e. Zoning Officer                       $72 per hour
 f. Senior Inspector                     $72 per hour
 g. Inspector                            $62 per hour
 h. Property Inspector                   $62 per hour
 i. Records Administrator                $58 per hour
 j. Administrative Assistant             $58 per hour
 k. Office Assistant                     $32 per hour
 
Fees of other professionals shall be charged at the rate paid by the Township
for such services.
 
3. Realty Tax Certification                   Fees
 a. Single Tax Parcel                         
  i.   Includes preparation of and mailin$35
  ii.   Duplicate tax bill provided by ma$5
 
 
4. Right-To-Know Requests Fees
Fees for Right-To-Know requests shall be charged in accordance with the Fee
Schedule established by the PA Office of Open Records as amended from time to
time by that Commonwealth Agency.
 
 
5. Liquor License Transfer                   Fees
 a. Hearing fee for liquor license transfer $2,500
 
 
6. Miscellaneous               Fees
 a. CD or DVD, per CD/DVD     Actual Cost
 b. Fire Escrow Certification $250
 c. Flash Drive               Actual Cost
 d. Postage                   Actual Cost
 e. Returned Check            $15
 
SECTION II: BUILDING CONSTRUCTION
 
1. Adjunct Fees                                                                   Fees
                                                                                  Up to
 a. Late Fee*                                                                    $1,000
                                                                                  (maximum)
 b. Uniform Construction Code (UCC) Fee                                           
  i.   Added to the application fee of each Building, Demolition Electrical, $4.50
    Plumbing, HVAC/Mechanical, and Sewer Permit
 
*Any person who commences any work on a building, structure, or electrical,
gas, mechanical, or plumbing system, including any demolition, before obtaining
the required permits shall be subject to a late fee for each required permit.
The late fee shall be paid in addition to the required permit fee in an amount
equal to the required permit fee up to a maximum of $1,000.
2. Additions Fees
2. Additions                                                  Fees
 a. Residential                                               
  i.   Permit fee per 500 sqf or fraction thereof        $500
  ii.   Plan review                                       
   1.   First review                                    $100
   2.   Minimum in event permit is withdrawn            $50
   3.   Each resubmission                               $50
   4.   All plan resubmissions after the permit is issue$100
  iii.   Accessibility plan review (if applicable)       $50
 b. Nonresidential                                            
  i.   Permit fee per 1,000 sqf or fraction thereof      $425
  ii.   Plan review                                       
   1.   First review (in-house, when possible)          $250
   2.   Minimum in event permit is withdrawn            $100
   3.   Each resubmission                               $100
   4.   All plan resubmissions, after the permit is issu$250
  iii.   Accessibility plan review (if applicable)       $100
 
*Floor area is computed from the plans submitted by totaling the area
determined from the outside building exterior perimeter dimensions at ten-foot
intervals from the basement level to the mean roof elevation or top of wall,
whichever is higher, or the uppermost level, excluding unfinished basements and
unfinished attics.
3. Alterations & Repairs Fees
3. Alterations & Repairs                                                   Fees
 a. Residential                                                            
  i.   Permit fee                                                      
   1.   First 1,500 sqf*                                            $375
   2.   Each additional 500 sqf or fraction thereof                  $100
  ii.   Plan review                                                    
   1.   First review                                                 $100
   2.   Minimum in event permit is withdrawn                         $50
   3.   Each resubmission                                            $50
   4.   All plan resubmissions after the permit is issued            $100
  iii.   Accessibility plan review (if applicable)                    $50
 b. Residential kitchen and bathroom**                                     
  i.   Permit fee for each area of renovation (plus electric & plumbin$200
 c. Nonresidential                                                         
  i.   Permit fee per 1,000 sqf or fraction thereof                   $850
  ii.   Plan review (in-house, when possible)                          
   1.   First review                                                 $250
   2.   Minimum in event permit is withdrawn                         $100
   3.   Each resubmission                                            $100
   4.   All plan resubmissions after the permit is issued            $250
  iii.   Accessibility plan review (in-house, when possible)          $100
 
*Floor area is computed from the plans submitted by totaling the area
determined from the outside building exterior perimeter dimensions at ten-foot
intervals from the basement level to the mean roof elevation or top of wall,
whichever is higher, or the uppermost level, excluding unfinished basements and
unfinished attics.
**Alterations to a kitchen or bathroom when cabinets and countertops are being
replaced in exact location as existing and no walls are being altered, removed,
or added, and all plumbing fixtures remain in same location.
4. Demolition Fees
4. Demolition                                                        Fees
 a. Residential                                                      
  i.   Demolition/razing of residential building                $400
  ii.   Interior and partial exterior demolition                $400
  iii.   Any proposed interior demolition                       $100
 b. Nonresidential                                                   
  i.   Demolition/razing of a nonresidential building            
   1.   Per $1,000 of estimated cost or fraction thereof       $100
  ii.   Any proposed nonresidential interior & partial exterior  
    demolition
   1.   Per $1,000 of estimated cost or fraction thereof       $100
 
 
5. Electrical Wiring & Equipment                        Fees
 a. New wiring, upgrades, services                      
  i. Per $1,000 of estimated cost or fraction thereof $25
 
 
6. HVAC/Mechanical & Fuel Appliances                       Fees
 a. Installation, conversion or replacement                
   i.   Per $1,000 of estimated cost or fraction there$25
 
7. New Buildings Fees
7. New Buildings                                                               Fees
 a. Residential                                                                
  i.   New single-family & two-family dwellings, townhomes, and buildings  
    accessory thereof
   1.   First 1,500 sqf                                                  $400

2. Stormwater Management                                                           Fees
 a. Plan Review*                                                                   
  i.   Sketch stormwater management plan for exempt activities pursuant to § $125
    206-16 
  ii   Stormwater management plan for regulated activities pursuant to §     $500
    206-5 
  iii.   Modified plan, resubmitted plan, or renewal of expired plan          $150
  iv.   Review of swales, berms, and diversions                               $225
 b. Permit Issuance                                                               $25
 
*No permit to begin any work on the project shall be issued and no site work
shall begin until the requisite plan review and permit fees have been paid.
Inspection fees will be billed by the Township according to its standard
schedule. The Township reserves the right to revoke any storm water management
permit for nonpayment of inspection fees.
Modification of plans: If it is determined that an existing storm water
management plan shall be modified, a new storm water management permit shall
not be issued until any additional review or permit fees have been paid by the
applicant.
Renewal of expired plan: If an applicant requests the renewal of an expired
plan, the application will not be approved nor a permit reissued until any
additional review fees have been paid by the applicant.
 
3. Watercourses         Fees
In accordance with
Chapter 240, Watercourses, a permit shall be required to stop, fill up,
confine, pave or otherwise interfere with or change the course of any drain,
ditch, stream, swale, stormwater management facility or watercourse. In
additional to the permit fee, the applicant shall pay the actual costs of any
inspections per each hour or portion thereof a Township inspector or the
Township Engineer is engaged on the work.
 a. Watercourse permit $225

3. Special Duty Fees
A fee is imposed for the use of off-duty Township police, in uniform,
providing police services to private individuals or corporations for special
duty. The fee shall be the hourly rate, per officer, determined by the current
Police Bargaining Unit Agreement.
 
 
4. Vehicle Towing                                  Fees
Additional recovery, winching, or cleanup costs shall not exceed $170.00 and
shall be reasonable in light of the fees charged by other reputable towing
companies in the area for a similar service. Fees may be set administratively
based on cost of services.
 a. Basic Tow (during normal business hours)      $185 (maximum)
 b. Basic Tow (after hours, weekends, & holidays) $210 (maximum)
 c. Vehicle storage                               $60 per day
 d. Administrative fee                            $60

SECTION VIII: ZONING, SUBDIVISON & LAND DEVELOPMENT
 
1. Hearing Applications Fees
1. Hearing Applications                                        Fees
 a. Conditional Use Application                              $1,000
  i.   Escrow                                             Project-
                                                               dependent
 b. Building Code Board of Appeals                             
  i.   Residential                                        $550
  ii.   Nonresidential                                    $1,000
 c. Petition for Zoning Change or Text Amendment             $250
  i.   Escrow                                             $5,000
 d. Zoning Hearing Board Application                           
  i.   Residential                                        $500
   1.   Continuance/Postponement Fee*                    +$100
  ii.   Nonresidential                                    $1,500
   1.   Continuance/Postponement Fee*                    +$100
 e. Zoning Hearing Board/Board of Commissioners Appeals        
  i.   Challenging the substantive validity of a land use $1,000
    ordinance
   1.   Continuance/Postponement Fee*                    +$100
   2.   Stenographer & Advertising (if continued for 2+  +Actual Cost
      nights)
   3.   Re-advertising (if postponed by applicant)       +Actual Cost
 
*The continuance fee is to cover the costs of multiple hearings. The
continuance fee will not be collected with the submitted application. Fees will
be assessed if hearings are continued.
*Applicant is responsible for the review fees of the Township Engineer and
other professionals retained by the Township to process the application. Such
fees shall be charged against the initial escrow fund at the rates approved by
Resolution of the Board of Commissioners and by the rates other professionals
charge the Township. Applicants shall replenish the escrow fund by a subsequent
escrow deposit in the amount of the initial deposit or the estimated amount of
the additional costs, whichever is the lesser.
2. Subdivision & Land Development Fees
2. Subdivision & Land Development                           Fees
 a. Plan processing                                         
  i.   Lot consolidation                               $250
  ii.   Lot line changes                               $250
  iii.   Sketch plan                                   $250
  iv.   Minor subdivision                               
   1.   Residential                                    
      a.   2-5 lots                                $200
      b.   6-10 lots                               $300
   2.   Nonresidential                                 
      a.   2-5 lots                                $300
  v.   Preliminary/Final plan                           
   1.   Residential                                    
      a.   2-5 units                               $150 + $30 per unit
      b.   6-10 units                              $280 + $30 per unit
      c.   11-20 units                             $430 + $30 per unit
      d.   21-99 units                             $580 + $30 per unit
      e.   100 or more units                       $720 + $30 per unit
   2.   Nonresidential                                $300 + $70 per acre
 b. Escrow fund*                                            
  i.   Residential subdivision plans per lot           $750
  ii.   Nonresidential – All Land Developments       $2,000
   1.   Additional per disturbed acre or portion there+$400
 c. Amendments to approved or recorded plans              $800
 d. Open space contribution** (3 or more dwelling units)   $1,500 per unit
 
*Applicant is responsible for the review fees of the Township Engineer and
other professionals retained by the Township to process the application. Such
fees shall be charged against the initial escrow fund at the rates approved by
Resolution of the Board of Commissioners and by the rates other professionals
charge the Township. Applicants shall replenish the escrow fund by a subsequent
escrow deposit in the amount of the initial deposit or the estimated amount of
the additional costs, whichever is the lesser.
**Paid to the Township as a contribution for the purchase and maintenance of
open space, parks, and recreation areas. A dwelling unit shall include but not
be limited to a single-family dwelling, townhouses, apartments and each half of
duplexes and mobile homes. The said contribution shall be made at the time a
building permit is obtained from the Township. When, at the discretion of the
Commissioners, circumstances surrounding the development of a site warrant
special consideration, this contribution may be reduced or waived.
3. Miscellaneous Fees
3. Miscellaneous                                Fees
 a. Fences – New & Replacement               $50
 b. Notice of Preliminary Opinion under        $300 + advertisement costs
  Municipalities Planning Code 
 c. Portable Storage Units (PODS)              $25 per unit
 d. Real estate signs in nonresidential zoning  
  districts
  i. Renewed every six (6) months             $50
 e. Sheds of 120 sqf and under                $50 per unit
 f. Written opinion of the Zoning Officer     $150
 g. Zoning Certifications                     $150
 
DISPOSITION LIST
Chapter DL
DISPOSITION LIST
§ DL-1.   Disposition of legislation.
The following is a chronological listing of legislation of the Township of
Upper Dublin adopted since the publication of the Code, indicating its
inclusion in the Code or the reason for its exclusion. [Enabling legislation
which is not general and permanent in nature is considered to be non-Code
material (NCM).] Information regarding legislation which is not included in the
Code nor on this list is available from the office of the Township Secretary.
The last legislation reviewed for the original publication of the Code was Ord.
No. 864, adopted 2-8-1994. A complete listing, including disposition, of all
legislation reviewed in conjunction with the original publication of the Code
is on file in the office of the Township Secretary.
§ DL-1.   Disposition of legislation.
